The place was a bit empty (just three other people), so I decided to go on in and order a slice of Pepperoni.

Now, I was born in Chicago and just recently moved to the Bay Area from New York City, so I think I have a pretty good opinion on what good pizza is. I was a bit worried coming to the West Coast, since I just love me a good slice of pizza, and didn't think I would find pizza as good as the ones I had in NYC or Chi-Town. Za destroyed those worries. Not only was the slice huge, it was one of the better slices of pizza I've had in my life. Seeing that there was beer, I ordered some of the local selection (Anchor Steam), which along with my awesomely huge slice of pizza definitely hit the spot for the afternoon.

One of the employees (perhaps the owner, not quite sure) was assembling some pizza boxes close by, and I told him about my worries and how they were gone now. He thanked me, then proceeded to tell me about two other places around San Francisco where they also had good pizza. I don't think anyone else would've sent me someplace else and potentially lose my business. But he seemed to genuinely care about my pizza cravings. That's just plain awesome.

Whenever I'm around San Francisco again, I'll definitely make the sacrifice of taking my non-exercised self up those hills for another slice. It's worth it.
author: Dennis M.

description: Pretty darn good pizza. We go for the pesto with roasted garlic, feta and mushrooms... drooling on my keyboard just thinking about it. Delivery is usually pretty quick and their salads aren't half bad either. Overall a good neighborhood pizza joint.
author: Kalie M.

description:
Best Pizza in SF hands down. Best salads too. How is this you ask? Let me tell you... OMG the DA VINCI pizza is soooo good with sausage and bell peppers on a thin corn meal crust... yum! The MONET GARDEN SALAD is ammmaazzing. Make sure to get chicken with that and the basil vinaigrette dressing.. so yum! 

Thanks ZA, you guys are the besssst.
author: Brian B.

description:
In a review before mine, Tetty B. wrote, "I live 5 blocks away from Za Pizza." Tetty, you are so damn lucky! 

We counted the blocks (Thank you Yelp map), and we live 63 blocks away. You can't put a distance on great pizza, can you? So we put on our best walking shoes and set out. It's that good. Burn em' before you eat em' I say. We took a cab back. We wanted the pizza to last. 

Some of the best pizza in San Francisco, definitely the best pizza by the slice. The crust is fantastic and their original creations are always za best!

Grab a seat outside, have a beer, and wave the slice of pizza in the air to the riders on the Cable Car rolling by. Lazy fools!
author: Michael R.

description:
As a precursor to today's abundance of acronyms, the 80's were about abbreviation. "za" for pizza, "rents" for parents, "boho" for bohemian.  Things seemed so much simpler back then.  While you were out, you didn't talk on the phone.  Food was food, not foam.  No one knew what a gastrique was, or cared.  Coffee was something you had at a diner, for 50 cents and free refills.

Za feels like a time capsule of a simpler time.  Small and casual, it has a friendliness that made me feel very St. Elmo's Fire, in the best possible way.  You can picture yourself there with your best buds, laughing and enjoying the time of your life.  The staff is great, the pizza is awesome, and you get all kinds of people in there, simply enjoying a slice or two.

I wouldn't call it thin crust, and I wouldn't call it thick crust.  It's regular crust.  Toppings range from the simple to the more inventive, but nothing too exotic.  Slices are huge, and taste great with an ice cold beer from the tap.

This is exactly what a neighborhood pizza joint should be, and if it were not across town, I would be there every week.  If you are in the area, take a chill pill and head on over to Zas.  It's totally tubular!
author: Liz S.

description:
My favorite local pizza joint. Their cornmeal-dusted thin crust is fantastic. The price is on the higher side, but you do get a giant pie in return. Their specialty pies are fancy and tasty (e.g. potato pesto), though I sometimes wish they also had more traditional combos as well, like buffalo chicken (my personal favorite).

The folks are real nice too, but sometimes service slows down when things are super busy, so just sit back, drink your beer, and enjoy the artwork on the wall.
author: Vickie C.

description:
Seating
When we first arrived at Za, we noticed it was full! There are 4-5 tables inside, and I think 1 or 2 outside. Luckily, an employee let us know about an empty table (it just had pizza boxes resting on it, which he moved). There are customer drawings hanging up on the walls that are fun to look at.

Ordering
You can order a slice, but since those are have been sitting out and get reheated, we opted to order a pizza to get the freshest experience :) When we couldn't decide between Moma and Potesto, he said we could get half and half :) He showed us the size of a medium and a large. The medium is HUGE, so we got it. I think it has 8 big slices. The wait wasn't bad, maybe 15 minutes.

Food
Yum! My boyfriend and I really liked the Potesto. I used my fork to cut the garlic into smaller pieces so that I could spread it out more, but it also tasted good when I bit into a whole chunk. The cheese was very flavorful! 
My mom thought the Potesto was bland. I agree that it might be even tastier if the potatoes were seasoned (more?). I ate the crust, which I don't always do with pizza, so I can say 'thumbs up' for the crust too!

My mom loved the Moma. She has remarked several times since eating there, "that pizza was very good. I would give it a high rating'. She knows we use 'review websites', and asked if we would write a review, so that prompted me to write this first ever Yelp review! My mom ate her leftover Moma slice cold for breakfast the next morning, and I had the Potesto for dinner. Both still tasted good! 

The only iffy thing was the water. We noticed nearby diners holding their cups up and examining them. We looked at ours and noticed we all had things floating. My boyfriend thought it was lemon pulp, but the sight of it grossed me out and I only took a few sips of my water after that.

Paying
Za is a really busy place. Lots of people come in for pick-up orders, and drivers head out on deliveries frequently. After we finished, we were waiting for our check and unsure how to proceed. My mom went up to the register, but it was so busy and she's short, that another customer walked up later and got his bill first. I had my boyfriend go up and he was able to get their attention. We asked if they had any foil because we just had 2 slices left and didn't want a big box (plus tiny hotel fridge!). The same guy that helped us earlier got us the foil :) I also saw him constantly seating people and busing tables. They take credit card payment.

Final Verdict
We're just visiting California, otherwise we would definitely go back and try other toppings, like Vincent Van Dough!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Za Pizza is delicious thin-crusty heaven. I have been coming here at least once every other week for the past 9 months, and I'm not even bordering on tired of it. The only downside I can think of is that they don't stay open late, so I can't end my night at the bars with this deliciousness.

The place is pretty small, coming with a group larger than 4 is going to be very tough. As it is, they only have a handful of tables to sit at. If you come for lunch it's much quieter and you can usually get a table right away, but dinner time is packed. 

The service is very informal -- you'll hear "hey man what can I get ya" instead of "may I help you sir." They usually are way too busy to stand around chatting with you or waiting for you to make up your mind so I recommend hanging back with a menu until you know what you want, then approach the counter to order.

The individual slices for sale are huge - 1 slice will satisfy many people (though I can't help but indulge myself in a second). 

Basically, this pizza is the best in the city. Your taste buds deserve it.
author: Kevin M.

description: Fresh, delicious, friendly. Only second to Tomaso's, which is double the price. I love this place.
author: Akash C.

description: Love this pizza! The veggies are always perfect, I love the soft crust and I never have to blot the grease off. Also we've ordered delivery from here 3 times and it has always arrived in a timely manner and hot! I admit it is weird that they don't ring your buzzer, I was confused when he called and said "I'm double parked," I was like "who are you," so that seemed strange. I think they should tell customers when they order to expect a call and to be prepared to go outside.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Aside from the rude guy on the phone, the RIDICULOUSLY RUDE DELIVERY guy, the pizza was one of the best in SF. I always get the one with onions, peppers and sausage and it is divine!
But seriously, the delivery guy was so horrendous we questioned whether to order from them again. He showed up at our place and didn't ring the doorbell. Well he sat in his car and called my cell phone which was on vibrate in the next room. Its a delivery I'm waiting for the door bell to ring not my phone! 5 minutes later I saw some missed calls while he called back again. when I answered he said he's been sitting in the car and is on his way back to the restaurant. I offered to come down and get the pizza, he said he was already on his way back because he could find parking. So I started trying to find another place to deliver.  5 minutes later he called and asked if I was' coming down to get my pizza or what.' Atrocious!

Amazing pizza, but RIDICULOUSLY rude staff. so 3 stars in my book.
author: M J.

description:
As much as I love Amici's (and I do), Za is serving up the best pizza in SF.  Their super thin crust with a dusting of cornmeal to get it off the oven floor, inventive and super fresh toppings (OMG, POTESTO, my darling!!) and delectably dressed salads kept me waddling in, well into my ninth month of pregnancy.  It's fun, too, that Buzzy and co. remember you from visit to visit, even if you've let unforgiveable months pass between outings.
It's true that there are some lower-level employees who aren't super friendly and don't leap to serve with alacrity, but I suspect there's a language-barrier-induced shyness that I'm happy to forgive.  Also, as to the delivery delays, they've got two guys in two cars going all over the city; if you want 30-minute pizza, order from Round Table or Domino's and weep while you eat your insta-pizza.
author: L D.

description: This place was such a good find. I went on a Tuesday night while waiting to be seated at Ozoke, and they have a handful of good beers on tap. I haven't actually had the pizza yet since we were waiting for sushi, but it looked incredible and I'll update the review after I go back and try that food! Very tiny, probably best for two people. Super friendly service.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I love the atmosphere of Za.  It's super laid back, the bartenders/servers are super friendly, and the pizza is quality.  

This is your place if you like thin (but not too thin) pizza.  I used to live across the street from here and went here multiple times.  The Scaliano is the one I've had most recently - comes with spicy sausage, garlic, and green onion.  Mmm...The other specials are great, and the basic pepperoni never fails to please either.   Only downfall is that it's a bit expensive for pizza.

Follow it up with Swensen's deliciousness next door!
author: Jenny W.

description:
So I havent physically BEEN to Za, but I ordered in one night and was one very happy lady!

They got my pizza here quickly and it was delish! My boyfriend even liked it despite it being a thin crust pizza--this is a big deal!

Definitely will be ordering from Za again.
author: Britney K.

description:
Q:  What's the fastest way to break a Yelping hiatus? 
A:  Being rubbed ZA wrong way.

Last night, my roommate and I each spent 25-30 minutes on hold. No one ever came back on the line after immediately putting us on hold. It's good pizza, don't get me wrong...  but sorry, there's no way it's so busy that no one can take my order for over 30 minutes. 

It's the Potesto that kept us on hold, but ultimately our time is worth more than the service- and frankly common courtesy- we were extended. 

For ZA crap service, why the "A-OK" of 3 stars?  As I admitted, I've been on an accidental Yelping-hiatus. With full intention of cleaning up that accident, I had bookmarked Za to later write a review, and at the time of the bookmark, in my mind Za was worthy of 4 stars. 

Hope to update this review in the future... IF I can place an order when that time comes  ;-)
author: Courtney B.

description:
I really like this place.  It's very relaxed and the service is so friendly and accommodating.  It's a decent value too.  With the right order you can get out of there for under $25 for 2 people. 

OH, and the pizza is great, too!  It's a nice, thin crust pie, resembling NY-style but not quite as thin or greasy.  Toppings are imaginative, generous and fresh.  Salads are huge, delicious and littered with all sorts of fresh veggies.  A small is big enough to split between 2-3 people.  

For added excitement, try the daily slice specials - they always have a unique combination up on the board.  Our next time, we're going to be daring and go for the pesto option rather than traditional sauce. This is a great place to stop in for a casual slice and a beer.  My new neighborhood pizza joint.
author: Lindsay N.

description:
Solid consistent Za. 
Everytime.
As far as pizza delivery goes, this is my favorite on the Northside!
author: J.M. B.

description: Got the Moma delivered one night for a eat-in dinner. Sadly I couldn't use the coupon because it wasn't printed out. That's silly. Also, it was almost $30, and though it was a very large pizza it seems expensive. We enjoyed the pizza, but felt like there are better options in the area (Tony's, Pizza Nostra, etc.)
author: Emily S.

description: Sadly, about the only thing gourmet about this pedestrian pizzeria is the 5-Series BMW parked out front.  On the recommendation of a friend, I show up with my brother and order a few to-go slices of the 'Van Dough' (tomatoes and cheese).  Easy enough.  But when we go to sit down at an empty table we're told by one of the owners, quote: "We're trying to be a restaurant.  If you want a place to sit down with your to-go order, try the curb."  Needless to say, we ate our insipid, uninspired slices in the car.  To concur with the other sensible Yelpists out there: these people need to get over themselves.  Little Star could beat the life out of this bogus Russian Hill beanery with a broken pinky finger.
author: Morgan W.

description: I couldn't be happier with Za. The pizza is wonderful, the service is friendly, the price is right, and it's dependable. I've been there 5 or 6 times in the last year and there's never been a single misstep. Go to Za!
author: Da Wei S.

description:
When man created fire, he rejoiced.

But when man created Za's, the world rejoiced.

Sitting on the same beautiful path that houses another personal favorite, Frascati, Za's pizza is a treat that should be indulged in. Frequently.

A small place in Russian Hill, it plays host to a wonderful array of pies that come out waiting to deliver a knock out. 

A hungry group of us meandered here after a perfect trip to wine country and threw in our order for a Da Vinci's Palette ( Red and green peppers, spicy sausage and onions ) and the Salvador Dali ( Roasted Chicken, sun dried tomatoes, fresh pesto and tomato sauce )

Orders keep the room busy, but the attendants are friendly, open to conversation and serve their stellar pizza with a confident grin.

The Da Vinci won me over. Quickly. Spicy sausage took center stage, and left your tongue reeling in euphoria. The fun combo of bell peppers brought on the final kick that left you supremely content.

Needless to say, the Salvador was a winner as well.

Za's is a neighborhood institution and delivers a pizza in it's own class.

And a nice little side note: When dining here, if you're craving the delectable bread pudding from Frascati, they will deliver it to you.

Yup, sometimes life just is that perfect.
author: Mike K.

description:
I generally don't do pizza too often (semi lactose intolerant), but when it was suggested as a solution to our growling stomachs, who was I to say no?

I'd heard good things about Za, and am happy to report I was not let down. I think, quality-wise, it slots in nicely between the low-end, high-volume places like Little Star / Pizza Orgasmica, and the "high-end" places like Pizzeria delFina & Paulines. The shop itself is small (5 tables?), with probably 8 stools along the bar. We sat at the bar, and it was the best decision ever.

After deciding on toppings, we put in an order for a medium pie w/ pepperoni, ham & pineapple. A little twist on the classic Hawaiian if you will. I unfortunately forget the waiter/bartender's name, but he suggested we add some jalapeno peppers to a small portion of the pizza as it would really contrast nicely w/ the sweetness of the pineapple. DAMN he was right. It was delicious! Served fresh out of the over, I'd recommend giving it a few minutes to cool down (I like my cheese to be a bit firmer) before digging in.

We got about 4 slices each out of the medium size, which was more than enough to fill us up & still have a piece leftover for a snack. 

To accompany the pizza we had a few beers (Anchor Steam & Sierra Nevada if you must know) which washed it down well. 

All said, the food was great, the price was so-so. 1 medium pizza + 3 toppings + 4 beers = ~$49 including tax & tip ($8 tip on a base of $41). It won't break the bank, but you can certainly find a cheaper place around. That said, you don't get the nice warm atmosphere, the stellar recommendations, or the delicious pizza that come with Za. Definitely give it a shot.
author: Aaron M.

description: Delicious!! The perfect amount of dough, sauce, cheese, and toppings... I had the Moma. Artichoke hearts were a perfect size to get in one bite. I am visiting my brother who is local and he recommended Za. We placed an order to pick up. The basil pulled everything together. I can't wait to try the rest. I know I will be satisfied.
author: Nickie S.

description:
They suck.

Pizza is meh.  Customer service blows.  Left us hanging on hold for 15 minutes, called back and they hung up on us.  Called Paxti's and they answered on the first ring and were way pleasant.  No reason to deal with Za-tards anymore especially since the pizza kinda sucks.
author: Brian C.

description:
This is one of the best pizza places in the city. Whenever I try to branch out and order from anywhere else, I'm usually disappointed that it's not as good as Za. Their sweet sicilian sausage topping is absolutely amazing, and their cornmeal dusted crust has great flavor. If you live in the Nob Hill area, this is the only place you should be ordering from.

My only minor complaint is with their delivery. Every time we order, we have to leave our apartment and go down to the lobby to get it from the driver. They claim it's because of  'parking issues' in the area we live, but every other restaurant we order from seems to have no problem bringing it to our front door.
author: Andi S.

description: Great pizza and staff.  Nice and thin crust with great flavor and some excellent toppings like the ground sweet Italian sausage.  Good Caesar salad for a pizza place too.
author: Trevor R.

description: Expected more out of this place when I read the reviews. We got it delivered and it came in a decent amount of time. The pizza was good but unspectacular. The hawaiian had unusually thick chunks of pineapple, which was a little puzzling, and one edge of the crust was curled up and slightly burnt. I was hungry and it tasted good so we didn't have any leftovers, but there are better thin crust options in the city, especially for the prices you pay here
author: Taylor C.

description: Incredibly delicious pizza and amazing customer service.  Thanks for making our boy's 11 birthday so special, Brooks!!! We'll be back for more of that delicious pie.
author: Jason M.

description:
OFTEN CLOSES LONG BEFORE 10:30PM.  Yeah, I know that the hours say it is open until 10:30pm, but I have seen the doors closed as early as 9:15pm.  So, unless it is a Friday or Saturday night, don't show up late and expect that they will be open.  

The owner is a really friendly, genuine guy who is around a lot during the day.  However, when he isn't around, the service can be spotty.  Most of the guys who work there hustle.  However, several others consider it unfair that they have to work at all.  But it isn't that big of a deal because the place is so small that you can always get someone's attention.  

The pizza is always good.  Huge slices for $4.xx.  I have been showing up once a twice a week for years.

SUMMARY:  Definitely go for the pizza; be prepared for the occasional lackadaisical server;  don't show up too late and expect that they will be open.
author: Walter E.

description:
I can't say, definitely, whether Za makes the best pizza in the city, and not because I haven't tried most of San Francisco's pizza. Rather, it's because the experience of dining at Za is so pleasant that the pizza is an afterthought (which isn't to say the chef's there don't take their pies seriously -- they do). 

It was my second visit to Za that really sealed the deal. You have to understand that Za is not a formal restaurant -- however, unlike so many other "casual" restaurants, Za does not make its customers fend for themselves or be otherwise uncomfortable while they wait for a table. When I showed up with a group of four, the waiter/host went out of his way to make us comfortable, make sure we got the next table (without our having to scramble for it), and get our pizza order rolling. The place was ridiculously busy, but he didn't act rushed or bothered at all, taking time to joke with us and hook us up with water. Again, this is a casual place with casual prices -- tips are not something he can expect. 

In addition to the pizza, they serve respectable and awesomely huge salads (one fed all four of us with salad leftover). And of course, you can't go wrong with that stretch of Hyde St. -- easily one of the most romantic blocks in the city.
author: Adam M.

description:
This was some of the best damn pizza I'd had in the Bay Area and go figure my first time to eat there was my last day in SF.  It was a great last day with good friends and great pizza pie.  The meat slice was awesome!  They are sooo kid friendly which was nice for us(a 2 year old and a 4 week old!)

Not much more to add....good pizza, good people, good service, i would definitely go back!
author: Tiff G.

description: This business is clearly averse to the LGBT community as per my experience here this evening. If you're not white and straight, do not expect any service here. The quality of their products is clearly outmatched by their discriminatory practices, most definitely not in keeping with SF values.
author: Norman M.

description: Best Nob Hill neighborhood pizza. So delicious, crispy crust, awesome topping options. love love
author: Donna H.

description: Damn good pizza, very cool atmosphere,  really nice people working there.  Just a couple doors down there is an upscale place where people seem to be there to impress others and then this place where people go to be impressed by great pizza.  The toppings were fresh and flavorful, loved the sausage, thin crispy crust, huge slices!  Large is 18 inches.  Also, not crazy greasy like NY style pizza I've had.  Really like that they have GOOD vegetarian options.  Book marked this one for the next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Lorenzo R.

description: This is one of my two or three favorites in The City for pizza.  I can't believe so many people are ragging on the service.  I have never had a bad experience at Za.  The pizza is perfectly thin with tasty sauce and real toppings.  A pint of draft beer goes down easy and they usually have something new on tap.  My wife loves the potato pizza which you can't find anywhere else.  I think all pizza places in SF need to sell by the slice and this one does.  It's also a great location where you can watch the tourists go by on the cable car.  Peaceful and relatively quiet with trees all around.  I'm glad I don't live closer or I would eat way too much pizza at Za.
author: Michael B.

description: This place used to be a lot better.  Lately we order only from Amici's, but we decided to order from Za tonight.  I ordered a cheese with broccoli and roasted garlic. The crust was thick, the broccoli was minimal, and the garlic was in no way roasted. It seemed like they blanched it in boiling water for a few seconds.  In addition, there was chopped fresh garlic on a few of the slices.  I didn't order the chopped fresh garlic , and on top of the practically raw garlic cloves, it was not at all welcome. Sometimes it's best to stick to the tried and true.
author: Martha M.

description: If I could give this joint less than 1 star I for sure would  Took an EPIC long time to get back to me off hold.  Then when I ordered, I was not asked if I wanted crushed peppers or parmesan cheese, so I called back and had to wait AGAIN.  Oh, ok, no problem, I got one packet of crushed peppers and NO parm!  The gy called and said he was in my lobby as I was at a hotel and I asked to have him call when he pulled in. FUNNY, as it took me approx. 3 mins to get down there and he was OUTSIDE in the cold wind TEXTING and also had attitude.   I have since called 9 times and NO answer.  He WAS Aggressive towards me and I will have AMEX reverse this charge and they can come back and pick this pizza up as I will not eat this cold slab!
author: Jojoeka S.

description: Apparently this place only delivers within a 3 block radius of its restaurant. This place is located in Nob Hill, which is only 5 minutes from my workplace (Pier 39), and they told me they don't deliver to this area because they "only deliver in their neighborhood." Really guy?! Really? Thanks for nothing. Way to keep your customers, ass.
author: Krystle A.

description: Best pizza ever! I'll never forget all my stops to this amazing pizza joint. The guys who work here are awesome! I will forever love this place! Russian Hill gem...thank you Za
author: Ambrosia S.

description:
Found this place on Yelp one night when I had a craving for pizza but didn't want to order from the big chains like Domino's or Pizza Hut. The reviews looked positive so I gave the place a call. The person who answered was pretty friendly. I ordered a Medium half pesto chicken and half spicy italian sausage. (Sorry forgot the names). He told me that it would take 45 minutes...
Well an hour and 15 minutes later...I was starving, frustrated, and angry. I HATE BEING LIED TO! I finally got a call from the driver asking if I can come out to pick it up. Really now? So he handed me the pizza and I handed him his tip, which he looked unappreciative. Not even a "Thank you". he looks like he hated his job. I asked him if he had any pepper or cheese and he said that I have to request it when I ordered. Shouldn't all pizza delivery guys have red pepper and cheese on them?
Anyways, the pizza was a pretty decent size, cut up into 6 huge slices. However, it was room temperature. That's probably why it was late! It was probably sitting on the counter when the driver or whoever works there realized "Oh wait! This pizza needs to be delivered!" The pizza itself was very good. The pesto was very flavorful without being overpowering. The spicy sausage came with crumbled sausage bits and roasted red peppers and onions. Also very good.

Overall, pretty good pizza. Bad everything else
I HATE LIARS
author: Steven L.

description: Za pizza has Za worst customer service - it doesn't matter how tasty the pizza is.
author: R M.

description: If there was a way to give zero stars or negative stars this place would deserve it.   Their pizza took forever to be delivered, it was cold and my boyfriend got immediate diarrhea after eating it.  This place is awful
author: Country A.

description: Good pizza, but awful costumer service. We couldn't sit at an empty table to eat our slices of pizza, just because we ordered it "to go". The waiter was rude when he asked us to leave the place.
author: Vivian P.

description:
Mmmm I love this pizza! Especially the Salvador Dali,,
Double plus rad that the owner delivered my pie:: 
Thanks!
author: Eric H.

description: The pizza is absolutely amazing!! They have a variety of pies. I sampled the Vincent van dough, bluto, and straight pepperoni.  All were great! Owner Brooks is a great guy to boot!  We were on vacation and he gave us some great tips on things to do and see.
author: Scott M.

description: If you like thin crust pizza, there's absolutely no reason you should not try this place! The Moma pizza is fantastic, but you honestly can't go wrong here. I just moved near this place and expecting to go here pretty freaken often!
author: Stephen N.

description: Lovely local place to grab a tasty slice (or three) and attempt to consume an entire beer.
author: Poppy C.

description: I am not that crazy about their cheese, but there is no question the pizza is superb.
author: Adam S.

description: Great neighborhood family friendly spot.  We have two boys under three and they always make a special effort to engage the little ones and make sure they are taken care of.   Most importantly though, the Pizza is great!  If you like garlic the Potesto is a treat.  I've never had a bad slice at Za.
author: K W.

description:
Yummmmm....I used to live closer and come here.  their salads are fantastic as are their slices.

the guys and gal who work here are such a refreshing change from the Russian Hill/Marina crowd who frequent the area....
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
We had two of their specialty pizzas. I have to say that I like the atmosphere of the place. It's pretty cozy and friendly. The pizza was decent, but I would say that the crust beats the toppings.

The toppings were too finely minced for my taste. It kind of made it feel like a microwavable version you could get in the frozen food aisle. That's a little bit of an exaggeration. The size was good and overall it's a middle range pizza. It's definitely not a NY pizza, but I felt it didn't have any distinguishing characteristics, not the bread or the sauce or the toppings.

It tasted good, but I wouldn't say it was anything special.
author: Terry H.

description:
After living on Hyde Street for nearly 2 years, and willingly paying $7 a pop for countless slices of Salvador Dali or Vincent Van Dough pizza  (+ the intangible costs of awkward encounters with the flirtatious/borderline creepy guys who work here), I have finally acheived the Russian Hill Holy Trinity:

1)  Receive free pizza from Za.
2)  Receive free ice cream from Swensen's.
2)  Ring the bell on the cable car.

My Russian Hill experience is now complete.

(... extra points for the coupons they give when you order pizza for delivery/take out.)
author: Sarah J.

description: I ordered a pizza.  They never delivered it.  I called to inquire.  They did not pick up the phone.  I called the next day.  They said they would give me my next pizza free.  But when I called to order it, they again were not answering the  phone.  They do not answer the phone if they want to go home early or feel they are too busy.  I decided to walk over and ask about trying to make ammends for the first mistake.  They told me that it should be obvious why service is bad (They are busy.) and that it's not rocket science.  They also told me if I don't like their service, I shouldn't eat there any more.  And so I won't.
author: Marcie H.

description:
Favorite pizza in all of San Francisco (and yes, better than Tony's). Just A+ all-around (plus the staff is super chill and friendly).

5 Stars. Recommend to all.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Been here several times and each time I have the same experience. Four guys behind the counter turn and look at me as I walk in and say nothing, just continue on with their conversation. Then the guy in the back slicing tomatoes gives me a "waddup." The guy at the register is just plain rude. Dumps your change on the counter, tells you they dont accept credit cards while standing next to the "we accept visa, mastercard etc" sign, says 'whatever' when you say thank you...

All in all, decent pizza, SHIT for service. Maybe thats what theyre going for?
author: Kyle G.

description:
I don't eat much carbs...but when I do it HAS to be GOOD!  Ordered a large spicy sausage and mushroom pizza last night.  Hands down - it was the best pizza I've ever had.  The crust was thin and crisp, the tomato seasoning perfect and the sausage was ground up fine (just the way I like it).  The entire pizza was generously covered 'evenly' with all the toppings - not just concentrated in the center with bald edges!   

I advise everyone to check this place out!
author: Lorena W.

description:
I am a big fan.  I like plain cheese pizza and this place gets it right.  They seem to have some cornmeal in the crust or at least brushed on it.  Pretty tasty.

This place is tiny so don't expect a table unless it is a slow night.  Take out is best.  Delivery is available but it usually takes a very long time so I just go get it myself.
author: Jessica P.

description: Love their pizza. Love their cesar salad. Unfortunately I was surprised to learn tonight that they don't deliver "just salad". Even though I was ordering two chicken cesar salads that cost more than a medium pizza. That really doesn't make sense to me at all.
author: Justin F.

description: I owe this establishment a review. I've been lazy but the point of the matter is that I'm doing it now and that's all that matters. Their pizza is huge and it's freaking delish. Who woulda thunk it that their veggie pizza can beat most of the other pizza places that are famous for sausages and meat specialties. But lately I've been only ordering salads from them. They have a choice of Caesar or garden mix. With or without chicken, honey mustard or vinaigrette. Now if you have read any of my previous reviews I have a love for salad. Don't know why I just do. I think a plate of fresh salad would turn me on faster than micheal fassbender from x men first class. I always order the garden salad with chicken and depends on my mood my choice of dressing varies. It really is good. Even their white chicken breast meat that is premade is fucking awesome. And I don't understand why people say that people from za are rude. Maybe you just don't know how to order. Jk!!!!!! Try it out, you won't regret it :D
author: Lisa Z.

description:
My daughter walked here from the Argonaut hotel.  If you know the area you can imagine we worked up an appetite. Anyhow, we ordered a large cheese pizza.  The pizza was delicious.  Thin crust and perfect amount of sauce and cheese.  I definitely felt like I got my money's worth.  

The guys working there were all very nice and my daughter and I enjoyed watching our pizza being made. We had to slices left when we were done so they wrapped them up for us.  The pizza was so good that I pulled out the extra 2 slices and ate them as we continued our walk to Chinatown.  The pizza was even tasty cooled off.

A comment about the fact that they really don't deliver.  As I mentioned above my daughter walked to this restaurant.  The traffic on Hyde is ridiculous which I believe is because it is so close to Lombard Street ( the crookedest street).  I could be wrong but I would imagine that delivery could open a can of worms because of how long it would take the delivery drivers.  Long delivery time = cold crappy pizza.  So maybe they are trying to maintain the quality of the pizza and prevent too many complaints.  That is just my assumption since the guys I saw working there were all very nice.  

That being said, make your way to Za, you won't be disappointed.
author: T K.

description:
First experience at Za and here are my notes:

-Cornmeal crust...if you dig that then it's all you but I personally prefer the traditional crust
-Sauce...just about the most important part of the pizza next to the crust in my mind...not very tasty here
-Not many combo choices...a total of 7 to choose from and not very unique ones
-Price...expensive for what you get....$25 for a 18" large combo

Overall, your very average pizza meaning not great but not bad either but not exactly what my mouth waters for.  Will not be back as there are TOO many better pizza places in the city to choose from.  My all time favs are still Victors and Paulines.
author: Tina L.

description: Great place to get a slice. Good flavor and huge portions. Only thing I didn't like was how crispy the crust was, but other than that it was great. Some of the best pizza I've had in the city.
author: Josh E.

description: THE BEST PIZZA IN THE CITY! I am a pizza snob so calling it the best is a big deal for me. I love that they use real cheese & raw ingredients. They also make their dough fresh, have a few great beers on tap & serve wine. They trolly stop is right out front, what more could you ask for? This place is YUMMY & the slices are huge. Serves whole pies or daily special slices.
author: Brandye G.

description: Starving on a rainy Friday afternoon? Stop by this relaxing little joint for a monster slice of pizza and a beer. The slice had some crumbled sausage, green onion, and tomato. Very solid and piping hot. Couldn't help but get an anchor steam. It never hurts to have sports playing on the tube either. Definitely a great way to kick off the weekend in San Fran.
author: Joseph H.

description:
Had dinner here the first night of our recent trip to San Francisco.  

We had a couple slices of the potesto (potatoes and pesto), which was fantastic, and a slice of pepperoni, which was also good.  With a couple of Anchor Steams, and we had a filling and affordable dinner.

The place is tiny.  We were lucky to get a couple of seats.  If I were a local, I would get carry out.  I would probably get it a lot, actually!
author: Brian H.

description:
Wife and i were in the city celebrating our anniversary and wanted to go back to our first neighborhood in SF, Russian Hil.

We were staying downtown, so we took the long walk up the hill and checked out numerous haunts along the way.  Nob Hill Cafe was way too crowded, sushi didn't hit the spot and we weren't sure what to do.  While walking up Hyde Street to see if Swensen's was still there, it was, I was assaulted by an incredible smell of tomatoes and wonder seeping out of doorway.  Pizza?  For our anniversary?  Why not.

So after a few minutes wait we got a corner table out in the front where we could see our first (long long ago) flat in the city and started talking to our server who was an absolute doll.  We talked about the neighborhood and ZA and she recommended a chicken/red pepper/pesto pizza which was absolutely great.  What a crust, yes it was the thinnest pizza crust I have ever seen and it all worked very very well.

Sitting there we were reminded of the charm of Russian Hill, people out in the neighborhood just having a good time. Great atmosphere.

We couldn't finish more than 1/2 of the medium pizza and when the check came, they had comp'd the beers for our anniversary.  I have never seen a restaurant with 4 stars do that.

On our walk home through the city wife bumped into the box of pizza that I was carrying back to downtown.  I caught it before it fell and it is lunch today.

4 stars to ZA and the city.  Now if only I could get Giaoa to open a place where you could sit down and enjoy their pizza here in East Bay.
author: Jules K.

description:
I'm going to have to agree with the ever so smart (and beautiful) Rachel. 

The employees are rude. The pizza is overpriced. The toppings are sparse. 

I recently tried the garden salad with chicken  and "homemade" vinaigrette dressing and that was pretty awful (iceberg lettuce, bland chicken and pizza toppings with olive oil on top.) 

The pizza is decent but don't bother with the salad.
author: Alexa W.

description:
Great pizza for this city. Not a big fan on their weak crust but, it's worth a trip if your in the area. 

Not so much though for the staff. I watched a manager and his lazy staff quibble over why it's not ok to take a smoke break every 15min and leave the front counter unmanned. I waited 5 min for someone to show up and take my order then a few more for them to quit arguing.

The manager wasn't wrong, if the lazy sack of an employee did his job there would of been no problems.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Honestly, very good pizza....too bad the customer service is so poor I will never order from them again.

We almost always ordered for delivery.  We always asked for the driver to call our phone rather than ring the bell (dog in the house, neighbors with kids downstairs).  Rarely was the request met, but ok whatever.  

Just tried to place an order tonight with the same request.  The guy taking the order starts yelling at me, telling me they always called us (they didn't),  etc.  When I say yelling, it's literally yelling.  Rudest person I've ever interacted with - bar none.

Bye Za, nice to know you, better without you.  Judging by the other reviews here, I'm not the first dissatisfied customer.
author: Todd S.

description:
If you are looking for a dependable pizza restaurant that actually delivers a pizza, good luck. I ordered mine tonight and they forgot to deliver it. "the owner took this order," I was told. "well that says a lot about the owner doesn't it?" 
"yeah well I guess he doesn't really care" was the reply. They offered to make me a new pizza, but after waiting an hour for the other one, what would you do? "Never mind, I guess I just won't eat," I replied. They hung up with no apology. I think we all know that pizza restaurants like Za are the dirtbags of fast food and look no further than the next drunk looking for a pizza slice.
author: Etienne D.

description: I am writing to recommend Za not only for its outstanding pizza, but its exemplary customer service.  I accidentally ordered the wrong pizza, and called thinking the mistake was not mine.  Instead of making me feel like an idiot, Za remade the pizza I actually thought I had ordered, and redelivered it, despite it being the height of the dinner hour, and with the Giants playing the Dodgers!  Thank you, thank you, thank you!
author: Tricia H.

description:
Za benefits from it's location on top of Russian Hill. There is no other pizza restaurant unless you wander down into North Beach or towards Polk Street. And for those like myself that have lived in the area, there are times when you would sacrifice good taste for the immediacy of picking something up quickly. In short, they have a captured audience on the Hill.

The New York Style pizza served at ZA is not my favorite. The thin crust experience is not satisfying. I don't enjoy pizza with pools of grease collected inside pepperoni cups. It makes for a very soggy experience. There have been times when I couldn't tell if the pizza was cooked completely as the center tasted gummy.

I did try ordering smaller pizza's and found they were better and seemed fully cooked. I suspect the larger pizzas are not cooked completely.

They do have an interesting selection of pizza'a and sell nicely sized slices. But again because of the large slices, they don't seem completely cooked.

For those that like thin crust and your in the neighborhood, sure try it. For those that want something better, try New York Pizza on Polk Street or just order delivery from Extreme Pizza on Union Street.

The atmosphere is nice with a few tables and seats at the bar.
author: Peter M.

description:
It pains me to give this place only two stars.  Because it is SO close to my house - potentially perfect for when I feel like eating like a fat girl, and I'm not saying I haven't picked up a pizza here before and been pleased.  But the recent eat-in experience with the fam was so embarrassingly bad that I can't bear to return any time soon.

Why?  The service was so rude I was speechless.  What is this!  How surly and angry and just generally assholey can one server be?  A sample of the comments:

When we decide, belatedly, what to drink:  (Sneer) "Oh, NOW you're thirsty".

When we get the pizza and request the check simultaneously (Little Bro must make it to the airport, hence the rush): "Cool your heels, man.  You just got your pizza."  Older Bro blanches.  No one talks to Mr. Hedge Fund like this.

Check is not brought, so Little Bro, surprisingly masterful of waiter etiquette, asks again, "Sir, may we have the check when you get a moment?".  Waiter (bigger sneer), "Do I look like a f-ing sir to you?"

OK.  One rude comment, tolerable.  Two, questionable.  But swearing at an innocent kid in front of Mom?  Unacceptable.

And even if the service were good, they use waaaaaaaay too much cornmeal in their dough.  Za, you disappoint me on too many levels.
author: Melissa B.

description: Great pizza. Great and friendly service. Anything lower than a 4 star is from a grumpy old sad soul who would complain about anything good and only vote for the bad.
author: Greg F.

description:
Ok, I was trying to think of some cute ways to work "Za" into my review...

Yow Za!
Za Right Stuff!
Who Loves Za, Baby?!  (ok that was a stretch)

But you know what?  With pizza this good Za doesn't need any gimmicks or catch phrases.  The caesar salad was nice and garlicky with homemade croutons and the pizza arrived hot and in well under the 45 minutes promised (more like 25 or so)
Za is now firmly entrenched in my holy trinity of pizza delivery along side Uncle Vito's and Victor's.
author: phil h.

description:
I just ate here tonight with a handful of other yelpers and although I will say that this is a cute neighborhood joint with a few indoor and outdoor tables and some laid back (re: cute) guys working here...  this place has been overrated.  The pizza is yummy, yes.  The pizza has a nice crust, yes.  But it isn't 5 star material.  Sorry folks.  
We sat at a table outside that was dangerously slanted (re: wasted beer potential) which takes the maybe 4-star mark down to a 3.  The caesar salad was delicious and huge and definitely can be split with 4 people... and they also have a few tasty beer choices on tap, but Little Star remains my fav so far in SF.
author: Karen K.

description:
Epic no-nonsense thin crust pizza.  Expect a slice bigger than your torso for under five bucks and more staff attention than you'd expect at a fancy establishment.  

We went in on a sleepy Sunday for dinner and were promptly given a table despite some wench dashing in solo to Bogart it (she was appropriated to the bar, take that wench!) and the food came out steaming hot in under ten minutes.  We ordered the veggie and the meat pizza, Caesar salads, and it was all pretty damn good.  The room inside is limited to about 25 patrons, but they also offer outdoor seating.  

I think I prefer this to Escape From New York on both Mission and Haight, and the vibe here is also more inviting.  There's beer on tap and large pies for about twenty bucks. Repeat!
author: niero g.

description:
Beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep, beep- what it sounds like when I call for delivery.

Thank gawwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwd- what it sounds like when I get through and order.

Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm, what it sounds like when when I bite into the perfectly proportioned cornmeal covered crust and tasty sauce and toppings.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I got a slice of scrumptious Veggie Pizza last night. It was so huge I thought I'd eat half and be full, but it was too good to put down! So I basically paid $3.50 for a full meal. Well, $6 including my ice tea and tip. Not bad though. 

I've walked by this location many times since I live one block away and it's across the street from my favorite wine bar and laundry spot. But every time it has been too packed to even think about fighting the crowd for a measly piece of Pizza. I finally noticed no line! hmmm... I'm hungry after my looong run, might as well top of my healthy kick with a slice of greasy delight. 

Now I get it. I get why the lines are long, why people wait hours, and why they are still in business after having only 4 tables in the whole joint. Well let me tell you, I am not a big pizza fan, but this was phenomenal. In fact thinking about it is making my mouth water. 

The pizza dude was pretty funny... since the pizza slices are pre made you cant add anything to them. But I wanted artichokes, so I asked. He said no. My pouty face must have shown, because he said, "just never ask again, this is the only time I'll let it slide because we are not very busy." But he had to throw in there again, "Never ask for additions to a slice!" I said ok... thinking, well... hmmm... 

The pizza left me very satisfied and I think it is the only pizza spot I will crave.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE:

"What kind of name is Za??? I'll tell you, it's one you wont forget. But I still wonder, why Za? Maybe someone can help me out with that one..."

Tank you Shawn G. for enlightening me on the meaning behind ZA!

Nothing interesting, but a short term for pizZA... boring... I want to minus stars for that one, but I'll let it slide.
author: Dee C.

description:
There are nights when nothing else will satisfy me, and I will stamp my feet and pout until the order is placed.  In the winter I want the Potesto, but the warmer weather means basil and tomatoes.  No matter what the season, the caesar salad is a must.  It's just darn good pizza...good enough that I don't mind if delivery takes close to an hour.

Update 7/31/2006:  Za just dumped my ass after, what I thought were, two magical years.  I'm apparently no longer in their delivery zone--I didn't move-Za didn't move.   If it's because I've gained a few pounds or because there is someone else, just say so.  Just say it, Za.  Don't make excuses. (Google maps puts at .9 miles apart with a 2 minute travel time).  Just tell me the truth, Za.

Update 10/20/2006:  Visited you the other day, and was totally sucked back in.  Totally.  You were charming, friendly, and quick to please.  What could I do but forgive your previous dismissal of me?   Sure, I thought I moved past this particular loves me/loves me not self-destruction, but I gotta say, regression never tasted so good.  Back to 4 stars.
author: L W.

description:
Service: Friendly staff

Prices: $4.50 per large slice, ~ $4 for beers on tap, typically ~ $20 for a medium pizza (but we somehow managed to receive a $10 discount, making ours only $10)

Anecdote: After a weekly Yelp group hike with DYK (Destroy Your Knees - http://www.yelp.com/biz/_Ugn_4Hm5cBAnpWuBqqvvw), some of us decide to eat a late lunch before parting ways.

Via mobile Yelping, Andrew C. searches for 4 stars or above pizza places, and finds Za Gourmet.  We drive over to Russian Hill and check it out.

I order a Liberty Ale on tap, and a medium pizza of the veggie pizza they were selling by the slice (but without cheese).  Upon hearing my request for a cheeseless vegetarian pizza, the waiter throws in mushroom and spinach toppings for free.  My co-conspirators each order a slice from 2 types of pizzas available by the slice.

Our pizzas arrived quickly, and hot and ready to be eaten.  By the time we finished, we were all full and satisfied.

When we got our bill, the waiter tells me that he comp'd $10 off my pizza.  Pleasantly surprised, a $20 pizza became only $10 :)

Thus, the total became $28 and change.  We decided to give $35, ~ 25% tip.  I'd go back to Za again to see how it would be a second time.
author: Lloyd C.

description:
I haven't eaten here. Not a single bite. But based on the Yelp reviews, I decided to call them for delivery. After giving my info to the guy on the other end, we had this exchange:

Me - "I'd like to order a large Moma pizza."
Guy - "OK, what else?"
Me - "Can I substitute the onions in the Moma for pepperoni instead?"
Guy - "Oh so you don't want a Moma." *cue sarcastic tone, as if you were speaking to an infant* "You want a laaarge pizza with muuushrooms, pepperoooni, artichooke, and baaasil."
Me - "Uh, yeah sure. What's the total?"
Guy - "$34.75"
Me - "Actually, just cancel my order." Click.

See, the Moma pizza is $24. But since you can't substitute anything, they just charge you a large pizza price plus the toppings. The guy on the other line could have explained that to me, and I would have continued ordering, but instead he chose to be an immature fucking prick about it. So while I mean no offense to anyone who enjoys this place and its pizza, they can just as soon choke on a fucking dick for choosing to be assholes to a customer. Way to go, Dickwad Who Answered the Phone, you now have created one person who is going to tell everyone he knows not to eat at your place.
author: Raymond P.

description:
In the age-old debate over the relative merits of New York vs. Chicago style pizza I tend to come down on the thin-crust side. Don't get me wrong, a good deep-dish pie can be a wonderful thing when I'm in the right mood (see my review of Paxti's in Hayes Valley) but there's just something about the feel of a perfectly done thin-crust slice in your hands (and your mouth!) that can't be beat.

All of which brings me to Za, home of the best thin-crust pizza I've had in SF so far!  The crust is perfection!  My current favorite is the Scaliano, tomato, green onion, spicy sausage and just the right amount of garlic.

The pizza alone would justify the 5-star rating but add to that the most amazingly laid-back and comfortable atmosphere around and you've got a real special place.  All the guys who work there are extremely friendly, it really feels more like somebody's house than a restaurant.  The employees seem to know almost everyone who walks in and they're also very nice to the happy tourists who come in off the Cable Car line.

One final note, if you happen to be a Dead-Head you will receive an added bonus in the form of a steady soundtrack of Grateful Dead (assuming there's no Baseball or Football game on the TV above the bar).  Sometimes they like to turn it up loud, sing along and play air guitar which only adds to the fun!
author: Mike J.

description:
Look, Za is a good pizza as far as SF pizzas go, but the best? Gimme an f-ing break. 

I'm not one of these people that's gonna tell you that it's all about Chicago deep dish or New York thin crust. A good pizza is something you recognize when you see it, and know when you bite into it.

It tasted good, but I've had better, and so have you.
author: Jason R.

description: Great pizza.  My favorite in the city.  Dine is best option.  They also have beer on tap. Their delivery can be really slow and a lot of times they don't even answer the phone.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Za's is in a dead heat with Little Star for best pizza in San Francisco.

But there are clear differences between the two.  While Little Star is famous for its deep dish, Za's is known for its thin crust.  When Little Star is packed to the gills with an hour wait, Za's is pleasantly busy, but not impenetrable.  

The gourmet slice specials are always fantastic, and wash down well with a Trumer or Hefeweizen.  My fave is the "Mo Betta Feta" with Italian sausage.  

The beauty of this neighborhood gem?  When you visit enough (or when he gets drunk enough), the owner will start buying you beers.   Now that's love.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I love lamp.

I love Za.

I am an East Coast transplant.  My pizza experiences 
were usually in conjunction with hockey rinks, Zambonis
and the sounds of ice skates being sharpened.

Za's got it all goin' on:

  *Simple choices - cheese, pepperoni and a few weird 
   ones potato and pesto (?), Nice thin crust with slightly 
   salty dough.

  *Nice, casual staff  - "You want a little more root beer 
    to finish that slice?" .... whoah, really?

  *Home delivery is just a good as a pie on Hyde.

I wish they still had that little stall on Polk St. 
I hate walkin' up that hill but what can you do?
author: K-leen F.

description:
It's not cheap, it's not fast, and the name is so very stupid that it kept me 
from going inside for at least a year. That said, the pizza is good, and 
proves that one can't judge a restaurant by it's name, no matter how 
dumb.
author: Max R.

description:
By far the worst place I have been to since I moved to the city!!!  I am a pretty easy going guy in my tolerance for horrible service but I don't have tolerance for treating people like S.H. which is exactly what happened when I went in with my wife.  While there they eye F'ed every single girl that came in, including my wife, who was stared in a very psycho stalking murder kind of way the entire time we ate (which was rushed by the sheer desire to shed the pizza boy's gaze).  Every customer that came in after us was ridiculed by the employees some times to their faces, we are pretty sure their was something racial said.  I can't begin to tell you how horrible our experience was here.  Like I said bad service never bothers me but this place put me in a horrible mood the rest of the day.

F Za's!
author: matt g.

description:
I had heard great things about Za so I stopped in last night to see for myself and I was not disappointed. Being from the NYC area I admittedly am a bit of a pizza snob and have been on the hunt for the perfect thin crust, delicious sauce, perfect topping to cheese ratio pizza since moving here and I finally found it in Za. 

When my boyfriend and I arrived there was a bit of a wait so the server set us up a table with two chairs on the sidewalk and brought us our drinks. There was a good beer selection and a simple house red and house white selection for wine, as a low key pizza joint should be. Once we were seated at the bar we ordered a large pie with sausage, mushrooms and peppers. The pizza came out and they did NOT skimp on the toppings, especially the sausage. The crust was delicious with just the right mix of chewy and crunch and the sauce was perfect, not too sweet not too salty. Thanks to the excellent food and GREAT service (thanks for the round of drinks, bartender) this is my new local pizza joint! Highly recommended!
author: Liz K.

description:
I had this yummy pizza last night during study group.  One of my classmates lives up the street from there and suggested we grub on some.

We ordered a large Salvador Dali.  And, just like the painter, this pizza was surreal!  (Okay, that was totally lame - sorry).  

Nice thin and crisp crust, a perfect ratio of savory red sauce, cheese, pesto and thinly sliced chicken breast.  A total winner!

Of course, consuming mass quantities of pizza was disastrous for our study group.  We called it quits shortly tafter consuming the last slice citing food induced coma as our reasoning.
author: Christy L.

description:
I live about 5 blocks away from Za Pizza, what a great pizza they have !!!
Delicious and always busy (good sign). People are friendly and customer service is great!!
Now I have 2 favorite pizza place: Za and Patxis in Hayes Valley !!
author: Ty N.

description:
The shameful thing is that a pretty good pizza is made completely undesirable because of the atrocious customer service.  The employees appear to be living in some sort of warped world where discourteousness, indifference, and dereliction of duty are a good way to run a business.
 
Service hasn't always been so abysmal.  A few years ago, the service and the pizza were both pretty good.  The pizza, thankfully, hasn't gone down hill as much.  The ingredients are fresh and toppings are liberally applied.  The crust is thin and crisp, with a dusting of cornmeal.  The menu includes several fairly unique and tasty combinations.  The potato-pesto-garlic pizza is about as good as anything green can get.  

Escape From New York Pizza on Polk (about four blocks away) serves basically the same pizza.  They get my money now because, in my world, poor service does not get rewarded with repeat business.
author: Tom Y.

description: I must say that this place is off the chain, I love the service and the pizza is really good and at a great price for the quality of pizza you're getting. In one word awesome.
author: M C.

description: This place makes me love PIZZA! You can definitely get tired of eating the same old cheese, pepperoni, and combo.... but this place brings in POTATO on your pizza with pesto.. omg delicious, juicy, warm, gigantic slice of heaven. I love this place, and seriously craving this as I write about it.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Pizza parlor or pick-up scene, you decide. Seriously, stopped in here last night around 9pm for a quick slice of pizza, there were tons of single-looking women distractedly checking out single-looking guys, oh and doing it over some pretty darn tasty pizza. 

Me, I was getting two slices to go, just taking it all in. I enjoyed watching the skater-boy staff getting ogled by three blondes, getting ogled back, kind of ridiculous and amusing and a little drunk all at once. 

Good times, but once again, yeah, the pizza is pretty good, comes out to something like $5 a slice but it's cut more like two.

Note: I have hear at lunch time, and of course the scene is much more sedated, it's actually what a good pizza joint should be, reminds me of a high school gathering place, in a good way, and with adults.
author: Nish N.

description: Really deicious crust! You have to like cormeal crusts, though. The rest of the topppings are ok, but I have to give them a 4th star because of how friendly and fun the staff are. Also, tasty beers and house wine is totally descent!
author: Kari K.

description: I honestly dont care how good this pizza is service is HORRIBLE. Orderes a pizza for delivery-came in about 45 mins. The delivery guy refuses to call on the buzzer to come up to our apartment and instead called me to tell me I had to come down because there was no parking and said "didnt they tell you that over the phone?" uh no because then why would you deliver? Then I go down & the guy is totally rude & says "see no parking" needless to say I didnt give a tip & he snatched the pen out of my hand. This isnt a cheap pizza & dont offer delivery if you refuse to deliver!!!
author: Kimberly R.

description:
The Vegi pizza are worth every penny. 

Go there atleast 30 mins before it closes. They run out very fast.
author: Chandrashekar V.

description:
What can I not say that's good about Za!  With the hundreds of pizza places in SF, it's been hard to find consistency, but that is where Za takes the 'pie'...

They deliver and the food always shows up hot and fresh, the Moma is the best with Canadian Bacon.

Love their pizza
author: Sam M.

description:
Corn. Meal. Effing. Crust.

Roomie: "Oh you hit up Za's? Can I snag a slice from your pizza?"
Me: "You can pry this box out of my cold dead hands after killing me and disabling my zombie body that comes back to protect this slice."
Roomie: "Umm. ok, dude whatever."

Zombies wouldn't eat brains if they ever got a taste of Cornmeal Crust.
author: Tyler W.

description:
The Goods:  Amazing Crust Edges (crunchy and full of flavor), Fresh Tomato Sauce (OMGdelicious), Quick Delivery
The Bads:  Too much corn dusting on the bottom, toppings cut extremely small so that the pizza lacked visual definition
The Uglys:  I couldn't stop eating it.

Ridiculously delicious.
author: Nuri G.

description:
Za is great NYC style pizza and my go to for Pizza Delivery... I've only actually been inside of the restaurant once or twice but each time the service was friendly and welcoming. All of their specialty pizzas are great but the Salvadore Dali, with mushrooms instead of sun-dried tomatoes, is my personal favorite.

Delivery is relatively fast and always friendly even on a Saturday night!
author: Thel D.

description:
I'm liking the Za experience.  You walk in, shout your questions over the counter.  Whoever answers your question, be it someone who's making food, the guy serving the beers, it doesn't matter.  Shout your order and they bring out the grub.

And this is some quality pizza.  

The crust isn't really that tasty but the toppings more than made the pizza awesome.  Bug chunks or roasted garlic?  Don't mind if I do!  Their sauce is pretty solid as well with it being reduced enough for the sweet/tanginess.

Solid food coupled with beer on tap with a TV on ESPN would totally make this a local haunt for me.
author: Allan C.

description: Just happened upon this neighborhood pizza place and glad we did.  They have really good pizza...the crust is extra good and the slices are very generous sized.  The service was very good and friendly.
author: William B.

description: Awesome neighborhood pizza parlor.  Been going there for years, usually pick up and go, but its great to sit down and chill with a beer.  Delicious pies.
author: R H.

description:
It's a toss up for me...Za or Golden Boy? Although they're both awesome pizza joints, they're like apples and oranges.  Za is for a thin gourmet style pizza pie.  GB is a whole lotta thick crust.

But back to Za, here's what I love about this place:

-Amazing pizza
-Great combos like the potesto (pesto, cheese and potato)
-Laid-back atmosphere
-You can pair your pizza with a salad

If you could only stay open for the late night pizza craving?!
author: Lauren T.

description:
LOVE ZA ...Best Pizza in SF by far!! I always get there slice special that has some combination of italian sausage and a bunch of veggies! So good and the crust rocks so it makes the pizza!

Always get a tastey hefeweizen beer while I wait and I'm never disappointed!! The staff is really cool (skater/bmx boys) and always keep things entertaining! I live up the street and it is my favorite Pizza in the city!
author: Stacey L.

description:
Christ this place is divisive!
Not that I portend to have the literary skills to solve this age-old debate once and for all, but I'm a fan.
I've eaten at Za and had delivery (which was, incidentally, painless and efficient...as all delivery should be...kind of like sex, but I digress).
While deliberately avoiding mutiny-inducing comparisons to New York and Chicago pizza, I will say that I enjoy Za's flavors (particularly their sausages), the thickness of the crust, and their sauce.  
The Scaliano is topping my list of favorites right now.
author: Auburn D.

description:
I feel the need to tell you a COUPLE OF THINGS ABOUT za.

1.  I AM A PIZZA PRO.

2.  I love cornmeal crust.

3.  Lately the quality of the cheese has gone down.

4.  I asked for well done.  I got less than that.  Edible..yes.  Za NO!

Slow down, don't cut corners and listen to your customers!!

Cheers Ryan
author: Ryan L.

description:
Wow! These guys have gigantic pizzas. 

Za's a tiny pizza joint but it's good. They let you create your own pie, as well as having various delicious pre-made concoctions available for you. The prices are reasonable, especially considering the quality of the food. The caesar salads were good, and provided some much-needed fiber. The za that we ordered was messed up, according to the waitress (something about how one half had a gigantic hole in it) so she gave us the slices from the half that wasn't messed up. A few minutes later, we got a whole circle of bread covered in cheese, tomato sauce, ground up spicy sausage and more. It was delicious, truly delicious. The large size could easily feed five people.

Service is a bit slow but their friendliness and generosity (instead of giving us another half of pizza, we got a whole one) makes up for it.
author: Martin B.

description: I was across the street doing my laundry and started to get hungry so I stopped in for lunch based partly on the recommendations from my fellow Yelpers. I had a slice of the Veggie Divine. The cornmeal crust is delicious and the toppings are plentiful. Very good NY-style pizza. The staff was polite so I have no idea what the previous criticisms about service are about...
author: Dani D.

description:
Sometimes a girl's just gotta have some pizza. No matter how bad it is for that girlish figure. So when the craving calls, Za is my new go-to. There are a lot of crappy pizza places in San Francisco, so I must yelp out about Za Pizza in Russian Hill. 

It's thinner crust pizza which is great because you aren't just stuffing yourself with some massive quantity of dough. However, it's not so thin crust that its falling apart (amici's gross). Also it has a sort of cornmeal sort of flavor and texture to it a bit which I actually love. 

Toppings are excellent. An assortment of flavors and very fresh. Large slices which are great. 

My failure to provide it a five star rating is that I think it is a bit overpriced and sometimes their delivery is slow and cools the temps of my pizza too much by the time it hits my door.
author: Anna S.

description:
Cornmeal. Cornmeal is the antithesis of pizza crust. It should never have cornmeal on the bottom of the pizza. In all my life, the only places that seem to do this cornmeal thing is Za and a place in Scottsdale. 

No. Stop the insanity.

Beyond that - did I mention I don't like cornmeal? - the pizza itself wasn't bad. I came here on a recommendation, and, well, it's the first time I was let down by the guy. It's the cornmeal. No, people, stop that.
author: Jeremy P.

description: We've been in SF for 15 days and already went to Za Pizza twice! The crust is absolutely delicious, with just the right amount of crunchiness . The tomato sauce is also very special. It's fun to sit at the bar and watch the pizza guy work the dough. Today is our last day in San Francisco, we had to go back for one last slice. We had to drive at least 15 minutes to find a parking spot, but it was worth it!
author: Juliane M.

description:
word,

So personally I've always hated the word gourmet. Gourmet is a evil marketing tool that restaurants use to charge more for something by pretending it more sophisticated/better than the average competitor. The concept of gourmet pizza almost seems like an oxymoron considering that pizza is the ultimate cheap college food. It would be like having gourmet mac & cheese (which oddly also exists).

Anyway ranting aside. If there was such a thing as gourmet pizza than Za would be it. In this case I'm using gourmet to mean "good." I've eaten at Za's many times and their pizza have always been great. I'm a thick crust kind of guy so their pizzas work nicely. They pizza toppings always taste fresh and crispy. That aside their food is still a little pricey, a medium pizza should not cost $20 regardless of how good it is. Their service could also stand to take some customer relations classes as well. But all in all the best pizza in the downtown area that I've had.

yups
author: david h.

description:
The pizza was good; definitely one of the better pies in San Francisco.  But even that memory fades in comparison to the horrendous level of service my girlfriend and I received on our first visit.

Now I know places can have -off- nights, but you can read the other reviews for yourself and realize that my being shitted on by the staff was not an isolated incident.

Basically, the entire staff decided to ignore us in favor of drinking off the tap, chatting with friends,  and doing anything but making pizza.  Our only savior was one of the Hispanic workers who seated us, took our order, made the pizza, and tabulated our check all by himself.  For his sympathy and charity alone, I refrained from flipping my table upside down and enjoyed their very gourmet pizza, vowing to never return.

I expect that you will read this review and still decide to go to check out the pizza.  That's fine with me, I just hope you don't have to tolerate their poor excuse for service.
author: Bihn K.

description:
Finally joined Yelp and now I have to take a moment to add my 2 cents about Za!

I have been going there for 13 maybe, 14 years. Best pizza place in the city and I have tried a bunch. They have it all!

Great pizza combinations, amazing crust, simple small place, nice staff and cold beer. 

It really is just ideal. Their only drawback is no parking. :(  Many a time the wife and I have circled for an hour or more to get a space. Totally worth it. 

The slices are huge, but don't let them intimidate you with their "Are you sure you can eat 2 slices" talk. Just order up. They are so good you will eat well beyond the point you are full ;-).

But if you go, please walk. I prefer it when I can park easily.
author: Alan B.

description:
Really love this place: laidback atmosphere, good beers and great pizzas. Been there 2 or 3 times (a little far from home), but had the POTESTO only on my last visit. Have been craving for it ever since...

POTESTO, for the uninformed is potato and pesto pizza. Couldn't imagine that this would work..love potatoes and pesto but the idea of both together was a little unappetizing. But the pizza just won me over....the baked potato on excellent pesto sauce. Just enough cheese, and the crust was also just right, not too thick. Washed it down with some fine chilled beer on tap.
On an other occasion have also had their house red wine which is also pretty damn good. 
Recommend having Svenson's icecream after this...it's a few blocks away on Hyde.
author: DJ R.

description:
I ate a lot of mediocre food this weekend so I'm cranky. 


From the reviews on here, it looks like I was there on an off night. But it was VERY OFF and I don't believe that a place that has 4 stars on Yelp should swing that much in quality. May be a good hit or miss place to swing by and take your chances on if you live in the area, but I will never drive over here again. Blech.

The service was deplorable. The guy spent a lot of time walking by our table, but very little actually stopping. The pizza could have been good, but it was undercooked so the entire middle of the pizza was soggy. It was so soggy that if you picked a slice, the cheese and toppings slid off the front half of the slice. That is bad.

To top it off, the fountain drinks were not right. I should have expected it, but I thought a Coke would improve my mood/experience.
author: Shal J.

description:
What's not to like? They have the best, thin crust, pizza and salads, one type of red and one type of white and beer on tap. Simple and uncomplicated! Embarrassingly, we are regulars and go in for slices (which are huge!) and salad at least once a week. 

Try the Davinci's, amazing... and their special slices of the day never disappoint!
author: Arin M.

description:
Za got 'tude, and its all good.

Music is loud and ranges from Boston to 50 Cent, depending on whose iPod happens to be jacked in. The hardworking staff put aside their high velocity Za-slinging only to snap towels at each others' posteriors and high five. It's a great place for people watching, with customers ranging from hipsters to elegantly dressed older folks on their way home from the opera. 

The pizza is good, normal crusted and comes in generous slices for $3.90. Two of us went through four beers, a tasty CeaZar Salad, and a half a medium pizza (took the other half home) for about $35.00. Hours are noon-10:00PM Sunday through Wednesday, till 11:00PM on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Delivery available.
author: Bill S.

description:
It's pricey (maybe I'm just old), but it's quality food. 

Being from New Jersey, I'm particular about my pizza. (New York? Puh - leeze. Even reluctant Manhattanites will admit that New Jersey pizza is better.) Outside of the Garden State, pizza takes a precipitous drop in quality as soon as you cross the Delaware. Most alarming are the things that non-Wiseguys will put on a 'pie,' whether it's chicken or pineapple or potato. In spite of my concerns, I've tried a number of the non-traditional pizza recipes at Za, and I'm shocked to admit that they've come up with a number of winning combinations - you got a problem wit dat? While their delivered pizzas are great, your best bet is a trip to the joint for a seat at the counter, a beer, and a slice of each and everything on the 'specials' board

Brooks is one of the nicest guys I've ever met, and when he's behind the bar, there's always good baseball chatter.
author: West R.

description:
A surprisingly good experience on a Monday evening. We are A 16 pizza obsessives--we like our pizza very thin crust, crispy with burnt bits and minimal but very flavorful toppings. We tend not to like most pizza from most pizza places but we were in the Russian Hill neighborhood and yelp said this was good, so we decided we'd settle for some mediocre pizza. But, Za was far better than mediocre.
We ordered two medium pies for four of us with a salad and got all of this to go, calling in our order ahead of time.  The mediums are good sized and we had pieces left when we were all finished. We were told 25 minutes until our pizzas would be ready and this was pretty much on the money. We made the decision not to eat in the joint because it is quite small, the atmosphere is rather minimal and we didn't think we'd want to linger chatting here.
We ordered the Scaliano, a mixture of spicy sausage, garlic, green onion and chopped tomato and a pepperoni mushroom.  The crusts were thin (not super thin) but not bready, doughy or pastry like. A nice bite and, upon a second heating the next day, quite crisp.  I would say the cheese was light for this type of pizza joint (which I much prefer). I don't know if it was straight up mozzerella because it did not have that way stringy pull that mozz has and it was a bit tastier then mozz usually is. (This is shredded mozz, not fresh).  
The scaliano was all four of our favorites. Its quite flavorful with the spicy sausage and the bite of the garlic and a tangy sweetness to the sauce.  The pepperoni pizza was good but not great. The mushrooms were fresh and plentiful and, surprisingly, there were more tomatoes on the pepperoni (even though we did not order tomatoes so they must have been part of the sauce) than on the scaliano. That might be my one complaint about the scaliano is I would have liked more tomato.
We sprinkled on little packets of red pepper and really ejoyed our pizza.
The salad was a green salad with green bell, red bell, onion and boxed croutons. They make their own salad dressing, but I'm not much of a salad dressing person so don't have much to say about that. It was fresh.
A note to crisp crust aficiado's.  We popped the pizza in the oven the next day on a good, solid cooking sheet and the crust got almost cracker like.
author: Vivek V.

description: I came in late afternoon on my way to the Fisherman's Wharf.  This was a good time, as I easily got a table and quickly got a menu.  I ordered the small Monet salad with Basil vinagrette dressing.  I also got a slice.  The service was friendly, loved the salad dressing and the slice of pizza was huge.  I really liked everything and understand why this place is popular.
author: Pamela R.

description:
