Za makes what I like to call "awesomeness pie's" Their pizza is just incredible. I find it difficult to elaborate because when I think about that restaurant and how to describe it my mind literally stops and focuses only on the memory of Za's pizza.

Strategic placement three doors down from Swenson's is also a plus :)

Za's Pizza is the best Pizza in San Francisco, I would probably fight someone that disagreed with me...
author: Isaac N.

description:
Salvidor Dali... that's some good shit.  Chicken, pesto (but still a tomato sauce), sun dried tomatoes... yum.

Not the cheapest pizza around, but worth the price.  I'd stay away from delivery unless you don't plan on eating for 60-90 minutes...
author: Niall H.

description:
Fresh-cut veggies, delicious meats and big ol' NY-style slices make Za some of the best pizza I've had -- in SF, and beyond. I can't stress this enough, Za makes an ultra-mega delicious piece of pie. 

The menu boasts a handful of "specialty" pizzas, plus two daily specials, and are usually about $4.50 a slice (welcome to San Francisco, rookies). A few beers are always on tap, plus their caesar and garden salads are also real tasty. 

A highly-recommended spot if you're in the area. Since it's a little on the pricey side, not recommended for delivery.
author: Jordan D.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars in a heartbeat for their pizza, but I have to subtract two stars for the staff that works this place.  I love their DaVinci's Palette Pizza and simply can't stay away from this place despite the awful customer service.  

If you order from here, expect to wait at least an hour for your food to come, so plan ahead.  When you call, expect to get a rude response and when you call again to check on when your pizza will be arriving, expect them to say "it's on its way!"  

If you go in here, expect to be given a dirty look upon entering as you will be putting these guys out of their way.  Expect to wait a while to get seated and expect to get treated terribly when you order your food nicely.  I honestly feel like a 5th grader being confronted by the class bully.  BUT THEIR PIZZA IS SOOOOOO GOOD!  It is just worth the torment and the frustration as the first bite of that pizza will make it all melt away!
author: Lisa D.

description: GREAT chicken Cesar salad, i don't really like thin crust pizza so i didn't try it, but next time i think i will :)
author: Courtney C.

description: Best pizza I've had in San Francisco to date! Great customer service...I will definitely come back!
author: Arlene T.

description:
I love Za. 

I come here enough that menus are obsolete. I know that no matter what, the best thing I can order is a veggie slice - whatever it is that day - and a salad topped with the awesome basil vinaigrette. The salad is always fresh, and even though they have generic croutons and less than fancy ingredients, the dressing makes it worthwhile. The pizza is always solid, but it's no flour + water or Pizzeria Delfina - so take it for what it is: a fantastic neighborhood pizza joint.

It's pretty much packed on any night of the week, so be prepared for a bit of a wait if you go around dinner time. The staff is friendly, if occasionally forgetful. They deliver, but I live so close that it's embarrassing to ask them to... and usually much quicker if you do take out.
author: Allie H.

description: I first came to know about Za Pizza from my boss which used to live right around the corner. He brought me there one day for lunch and I loved it. I live in Sacramento and I have been buggin my boss ever since our first trip to take me back to Za Pizza again. The slices are huge so we bought three different kinds and split them. Every pizza that I have had in my two visits has been great. We went at 2:00pm on a Monday afternoon and the place was busywhich doesn't surprise me since I know how good it really is.
author: jason r.

description: I was out of the country for two weeks and dreaming of pizza. We ordered a medium Vincent Van Dough (the basic--tomatoes, basil, mozzarella) as soon as we got in the country. It was undercooked, doughy, and not a great deal: $24 for a medium pizza? It would have been faster and better to get a frozen pizza--at least then it would have been cooked all the way through!
author: stephanie l.

description: This is a basic pizza joint with a twist!  Cozy space, great Za, local beer on tap, and the friendliest employees you could meet!
author: J C.

description:
Given the 4 star review, I was expecting some really good pizza.  Instead what I got was just ok.   Coming from the NYC area my search for the true NYC pizza goes on.   We had the Salvadore Dali pizza.  The sauce was good but it the crust wasn't too my liking, and I felt like without some added red peppers, that the taste was blah.   

Also had a Caesar salad that was decent but nothing to write home about either.   I guess I was disappointed based on the high ratings that Za Gourmet got on Yelp.
author: Matthew J.

description:
Came here after a friend's rec.  The slices were big and they had a nice thin cornmeal-ish-like crust.  Ate 'em with a fork and knife and a draft of Fat Tire.  Mmmmmm...

I have to say the people were very friendly.  After ordering at the counter, I pulled my wallet out to pay and the guy said "Don't worry about it, pay when you're done" and motioned for me to sit down.  I was surprised at his trust and immediately felt the neighborhoodyness of the place.
author: Ben K.

description:
Nice, thick and greasy pizza.  Definitely not for the weight conscious.  Only problem is, Za frequently gets your order wrong, and they are never apologetic about it.  "You forgot my pepperoni" and "This isn't extra cheese" comments get the "Live with it" or "If you want to order another pizza, we'll have to charge you again."  If you order in and present a discount coupon, the person taking your order will grumble, "I guess we'll still honor that, but you can't tip the delivery guy with it."

For a great pizza, I'm usually willing to tolerate the service, because they're so close to my home; although when they tell me the pizza will take *two hours* to arrive, when I only live a couple of blocks away (the hills are too steep for me to want to walk, and if I had the time or energy for that, I'd eat at the restaurant), I get a tad UPSET.

I wish there was a place that produced great pizza, got the order right, and was willing to deliver to Russian Hill.  I'd leave Za in a second.  They have an enthusiastic clientele, though, so I doubt they'd notice.  Even if they did, I'm sure someone would say "We're going to charge you for that!"
author: Giovanna M.

description:
I like Za for neighborhood pizza - it's great that it's down the block and I don't have to go very far for.  However, I've never been very impressed with it - I don't like the "corn meal" crust, and the thin crust really means everything just kinda slides off.  

Their salads are great though, and they always have some quality beers on tap and a crowd of interesting people around.
author: Tony L.

description:
Look, Za is a good pizza as far as SF pizzas go, but the best? Gimme an f-ing break.


 I'm not one of these people that's gonna tell you that it's all about Chicago deep dish or New York thin crust. A good pizza is something you recognize when you see it, and know when you bite into it.


 It tasted good, but I've had better, and so have you.
author: RugJones

description: My fiancée and I love this place. The perfect neighborhood pizza joint. Always cool people and great service.
author: Beau H.

description: A co-worker recommended us to try this place. We ordered 2 large pizzas to a small group at the office. We had the Moma (mushrooms, onions, artichoke hearts, fresh basil) with spicy sausage and the Salvador Dali (roasted chicken, sundried tomatoes, pesto and tomato sauce). I personally couldn't get enough of the Moma and the spicy sausage really brought the flavors together in this pizza. I ate more than my usual 1 slice which means this must have been good. I gave the other pizza a try and I didn't like the combination. The chicken was a little dry and I'm not a big fan of pesto w/sundried tomatoes. Other than that I like the crust - crunch on the edges and softer on the inside. I printed out 2 coupons from online so I got $2 off each pizza. It worked out to be about $9 per person for 3-4 slices.
author: Candace F.

description: Great ambience and location. It's no east coast pizza, but its cool.
author: Alex M.

description: Really good pizza. Awesome crust and fresh toppings. One star off because there could have been more toppings... the pineapple on our CB & Pineapple was a little sparse. But we'd absolutely order again!
author: M E.

description:
Oh, my.

Today was a pretty usual weekend day for me. Woke up at noon, ate a decidedly late breakfast. By 4:30, my roommate was preparing his dinner. Whatever it was, it smelled delicious. Consequently, I found myself feeling famished.

So I headed to Yelp to look for a great pizza spot and I found it, right in the neighborhood. Za's is fantastic. I got two slices, one with sausage and one vegetarian. Of course, the vegetarian pizza didn't feel vegetarian at all; just like a good simple tomato pizza.

And the reason I got two slices is because I was darn near starving and felt like one would not be sufficient. I was wrong. Each slice was *literally* larger than my face. After one, I was satisfied. After two, I was super full.

The pizza was thin crust. Curiously, the vegetarian pizza, which I ate first, was crisp and steady, able to be held with one hand (despite its hugeness.) The sausage was the opposite - super floppy and requiring cutlery. They were both delicious, though. I do wish that the sausage could've had the same crispness.

What really won me over was the service. I sat at the bar and got to overhear the incredibly friendly cashier clueing in some out-of-towners on some other restaurants to visit. After a few minutes, he reminded the cooks about my slices. It wasn't bad at all; they were on my table within five or ten minutes. I went at 5PM and it was already pretty crowded. I can only imagine how it would be during peak hours, but with good reason.

Za, I will be back. (perhaps for only a single slice, though!)
author: Chris L.

description:
I have yet to eat in the establishment,  but the pizza itself is amazing!  Traditional New York style, with your choice of a large variety of toppings.  

One of the best in San Francisco, and believe me I've looked!
author: kristen v.

description:
Brought friends in from DC.  Like so many, they willingly enlisted in Trick's SF Pizza Rodeo.  Need I even list the competitors?   Za, Little Star, Giorgio's, and Arinelle's. 

The verdict?  Za.  Hands down.  Three votes.  Unanimous. 

No neighborhood politics.  No preconceived notions.   Unbiased tastebuds introduced to each.

Once again Trick's Pizza Rodeo has solved the local pizza debate.  This time in San Francisco.
author: Trick C.

description:
All I can say is this: the pizza so good that one day I stayed on hold for 20 minutes on the phone to get through to place an order for delivery. I really wanted my Za. And that's because, for an east coaster like me, it's the best around. 

It does get crazy busy though, so sometimes service is not, um, overly thoughtful. I will say this, however:  I had a friend visit from Spain with his wife and kid and he loved the pizza there so much that he went back two nights in a row. The server hooked him up with some pizza on the house, which was just super cool and left my friend feeling really good about San Francisco in general and Za in particular. We love Za. Za good.
author: li a.

description: OUTSTANDING slices!  Two meat eaters and a vegetarian walked in to ZA, and all three walked out very very happy.  Perfect beer, perfect pizza, incredible value.  Service with a smile and nice art to boot.
author: Mark T.

description: I probably go to Za at least twice a week! I always come by and grab a slice to go. I've never dined in so I cant speak for that. However, the guys who work here are very friendly and the pizza is bomb. Their thin crusted pizzas all have fun names too.
author: Jacquie S.

description: Being from Chicago I have felt San Francisco is woefully lacking in the pizza department. Za is not Chicago style pizza, but it's pretty good anyway. We like to get the potato pesto pizza. It's pretty filling obviously because of the potato, which makes up for the thin crust that can sometimes leave you hungry. Za is better than your average when it comes to ingredient selection and inventiveness.
author: jen w.

description: So far in this city, my fav slice of pizza has been from Za. It's all in the crust baby, and I loved this crispy slightly salty crust. I had the basic cheese since that is how I rate my pizza places. If they can do an awesome cheese, the others are just as delish. I want to go back now for another slice.
author: Kelley D.

description: Slices the size of your head. Foldable to the max. A great location on classic Hyde St. This is a great place to sit down for a meal, but I almost always grab my Za's to go.  I mean, I need something to eat while I walk up the street to Swensen's for a cone, right?
author: Andrew K.

description:
This place has darn good pizza, but the service here is miserable.  I can tolerate mediocre service, but I simply can't stand going here anymore.  

There is usually a long wait, and of all the times I've been there, the employees have never made any attempt to facilitate the proper seating of the people that are waiting.  So everyone just hovers around and waits for a table, and sometimes when a table opens up it is grabbed by someone who just showed up, while people that have been waiting have to keep waiting.  Really, how hard is it to have a sign-up list?

But the truth is, you should be so lucky as to never get a table.  Because once you sit down, then you get to actually experience their miserable service.  They just don't care about you or your order at all.  

The worst part is that there are usually more than enough employees on hand, but they're often busy behind the counter joking around and talking to one another rather than serving the customers.

I'm really not a cranky old fart or anything; I've never felt compelled to write a review before but I just had miserable service there again last night for the umpteenth straight time, and I vowed to not return.  Of course, the place is always so crowded that they won't miss my business, but what're you gonna do.
author: John C.

description:
By far the best pizza in the city. Great tasting crust, fresh veggies, well seasoned sausage and pepperoni, and perfect tomato sauce. The proportions are large and the small salad feeds two. Great line up of beers on tap, including Anchor Steam. The employees are not that bad, mostly stoned out of their minds. For some reason they think louder music will cover the smell. Either way, a great local week-night spot.

Bad part is if you're not careful you can walk out $50 less for a quick pie. Also, you can't get individualized slices to go.
author: Mark P.

description: I stumbled upon this place long ago, and have loved it ever since.  I love this place so much that any time my friends are going to SF, I tell them about the pizza I got here.  Also, I will forever be in debt to my best friend who was in a vegetarian phase at the time and ordered, hands down, my favorite pizza -- pesto, roasted garlic and potato on pizza dough.  I make this pizza for dinner parties now.  Go eat here!
author: Liza O.

description: I really like Za Pizza. I love coming in here on a Saturday or Sunday or any week day after a long day at the office, sitting down at the bar and ordering the slice of the day. Huge fan. The beer is always cold, the pizza is always warm and the staff is always super cool and super friendly. It is a great neighborhood treat, and you have a great view of the cable cars coming and going.
author: sierra s.

description:
i used to live around the block and would come here af ew times a week

this place is just awesome, great palces for slices, the ppl here are hela chill

like the only way i could see you not liking this place is if you are some hick who likes hella shitty pizza

well i am all about class so i am all about za pizza
author: Cristopher K.

description: Chill atmosphere, tangy sauce. Cheese a bit rubbery. Crust nothing special. Pieces a bit bigger than orgasmica which is nice. Overall, very solid, but not extraordinary.
author: alex v.

description: Za is the quintessential San Francisco pizza experience. I'm from NY (well, Brooklyn) and there isn't a pizza place in SF that compares to the pizza in NY so I don't want to make any outlandish claims here. That said, I do really like the pizza and atmosphere at Za. There's no better way to spend a foggy summer evening in San Francisco than to hike up the hill from Polk St and grab a slice (gigantic!) and a beer at Za. This is the experience I most miss with my wife since we had children (the space at Za is a little tight for strollers).  Someday when the kids are old enough to walk on their own (and hike up the hill) we'll be back enjoying the pizza at Za!
author: Dylan S.

description: They can make some nice combos, however, the pizza lacks integrity. Got a cheese pie last nite and it was so soggy. Don't care for the cornmeal either. Staff waivers from good to "how the @$!k can 4 staff ignore me. Yes I came in to order pizza." manager is Yankees & Phish fan thus the extra star.
author: A.C. F.

description: Best pizza anywhere near Russian Hill.  Love the staff.
author: Quags M.

description: Everyone says SF doesn't have good pizza, but Za is an exception.
author: S Y.

description: I love pizza. This is the place for the best pizza when you need a satisfying pizza fix. I love the Potesto, Scalino, Da Vinci's Palette, garden salads. YUMMM!
author: Margherita S.

description: If you're a super honky like me then you'll know what I mean when I say that Za pizza is to me what Pearl Jam was to the mid 90s: widely-celebrated comfort rock.  And just like Pearl Jam recycled 70s guitar riffs for the 90s pop-rock palete, Za recycles 80s cal-cuisine for the New York palete.  Purists of the NY school should seek out Arinelle's in the Mission, while you hippie My Morning Jacket and Dave Matthews fans should keep on truckin' with Za's cornmeal-crusted jam-pizza.
author: Nom D.

description: I love ZA! You can get a slice of za and beer for under $8. Lovely spot in Russian Hill for a quick dinner out. Lucky for me, not so lucky for outsiders driving in. No parking EVER. I've made my friend meet me there and she kept me waiting for an hour looking for parking, despite my recommendation to bus it over. I was happily eating my second slice when she arrived....
author: Defne A.

description: "This Place is AWESOME. I love local places with great food and the owner on site. Small place with limited seating. If you are looking for Pizza Hut or California Pizza Kitchen you are in the WRONG place. If you want to eat great pizza with the locals you MUST stop here.  This place and the cable car were highlights of our trip.
author: Gale S.

description: Worst customer service I have experienced!!! When delivered, the pizza delivery man hung up on me and I had to call him back. Once I called him back, he was rude and inconsiderate. He hung up on me once again. As an out of town guest that depends on websites like Yelp to choose places, I feel that people should know what they are getting into. After I was hung up on twice during delivery, I called the restaurant and they were even more rude. They seemed to not care about the service I had received. I do not recommend this place and would rather have had pizza from anywhere else! Worst service EVER!!
author: K A.

description: One of the best by the slice pizza places (alongside Golden Boy) on this side of the city. Also, they have a few good beers on tap and the locale itself is exactly how a San Francisco pizza place should look. The best place for pizza in Russian Hill by far.
author: Richard J.

description: One late night after work, I decided to try za pizza as it is conveniently located half a block away from my apt.  I saw their menu and decided to get a slice of  cheese pizza and a small chicken ceasar salad.  The slice is about two slices and the small is really large that I had leftovers.  So, on tired late nights when I crave a salad, I get it from za's.  The pizza guys are so funny.  They try so hard to cheer up a tired working gal.  It's such a riot how funny they are!
author: Michelle F.

description:
This purely based off their pizza by the slice.

I went here to grab a couple slices and after I ordered they grabbed a pizza off a table that had obviously been sitting for a long time.  This pizza when ordered as a whole pie is pretty good, but they should put some sort of a time limit on how long a pizza can sit out.  The cheese was hard and the sauce was dry....I would have preferred to get a frozen pizza for less money.  No more pizza by the slice from here.
author: Matt B.

description: I've been in this town for a long time and eaten a lot of pizza from a lot of different places.  Za has got to be right at the top of my list.  The guys are super friendly.  Buzz (one of the owners) is really cool and always goes out of his way to talk to you and see how you're doing.  The pizza is by the slice or whole pie and they have a different meat slice and veggie slice every day.  The ceasar salad is awesome.  I stick with the pepperoni slices as they are great.  When we take the kids they cut the slices into diamonds for them.  The kids love it.
author: Brett K.

description:
I liked the pizza.  Slice size is big.  Crust in an east coast style.  Not super thin and not super bready either.
Service seemed like they didn't like us.  You know that weird feeling you get when you kind of get the feeling that someone thinks your a jerk, but you're not sure why, but maybe it's kind of like when one of your idiot friends suggests going to some dopey Marina bar and when you get there, you're standing behind some d-bag guy with too much cologne and he's yelling something to his friend across the bar.  And your idiot friend kind of reminds you of that guy and you need to rethink why you'd possibly be friends with that idiot friend, but then he hands you a beer and it's cold and soothing and you take a deep breath and think well he's not so bad.  Then that other guy with too much cologne starts yelling again, now to a dopey girl who yelling back with statements that always start with, "And then she was like...  And then he was all"  
Anyway, maybe that's what the waitress though of me and my group that evening at their hip Russian Hill pizza place.
Sure, I don't want to work as a waiter at a pizza place either, but you signed up for it, not me.
I'd probably do a take out pie, but not sit and eat there, at least not with any more than two other people, since the place is super tiny, with only about 5 tables.
Beer selection, fine, with Sierra and other NorCal microbrews.
author: Kev M.

description: The pizza at Za is great if you like thin crust. The Salvador Dali is an awesome pie I highly recommend it.
author: Jeff W.

description: Delicious!  We had cheese & the bluto special which was spinach, feta & peppers.  Wish we could find pizza like this in Dallas for $3.50 a slice...yum!  The employees/owner (not sure) were super nice too.  The guy made fun of me because I made the mistake of ordering two pieces as they are gigantic!  He was like, "You can do it!"  Luckily, my husband helped.  I know they deliver b/c I saw the guy running some deliveries while we were there (lucky neighbors!).  The people dining were friendly too- it was full on a Saturday afternoon, and a fellow patron offered us half of their table for us to sit & dine w/ them- rather than having to wait for a few minutes for an open table- very thoughtful!
author: Amy B.

description: If it weren't for the "pizza" in the name, I would've thought this place was a cool, laid back art gallery!  I always passed by it on the historic Powell cable car line and thought it looked cool.  It's a chill place to have a beer and a pizza, but vegetarians will be happy too.  You can order one of their GIANT salads for a great meal.  It may be the cheapest, best salad in town! and the pizza is pretty huge too!
author: Deanna C.

description: Might I recommend this place for the ladies in the house?  These boys love the ladies and, if I know ladies like I think I know ladies, most of you will love these boys.  Someone on some review described them as something like "aging skater-boys."  That's probably spot-on, although I'd put money on the fact that some of them still skate.  So sweet, though.  And so many free beers and glasses of wine for the ladies.  Whatever sport is in season is always on the tv; don't worry, though, they turn the volume down low and blast the classic rock instead.  Works for me.
author: Pammy C.

description: So its Sunday night.. family from out of town is in.. we just got done showing them around the city , 10 adults and 6 kids had to SQUEEEZE in!!! -Total chaos!!! We came in right before they closed. The owner was super accomidating, quickly took our orders and not too long after got us 3 XL pizzas! Amazing! The pizza was deeliciousssssss!,the kids were satisfied, we had beers and the whole family was satisfied. Thanks for accomidating us!
author: Karen A.

description: This place serves my favorite slice in the city.
author: Charles C.

description: Ok.  I'm having a real banner day in the healthy eating department.  First it was a breakfast burrito at Polkers, now this.  Ground turkey stuffed peppers just wasn't sounding so hot.  I gotta say Za seemed better than the first time I had it.  Delivery was fast and the pie was still hot.  More importantly, the crust was still crispy.  Nice touch is the hefty layer of semolina flour on the bottom of the crust--adds to the crunch factor.  I still think North Beach gets the nod in my book, but the gap has been shrunk and the race to Tastyville is most definitely on!
author: Daryl E.

description: This is the best pizza in the city!  Everytime I go there, it always tastes amazing.  I love the crusts!  I just don't get to make over to often because I live in Cow Hollow, but it is definitely worth the drive over!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Walked in after a long day of drinking beer at the North Beach Festival -- my group of 5 was seated immediately.  I've only been in SF a couple months so I haven't hit every pizza place yet  -- but so far, Za Pizza is the best pizza I've had in the city.  Our waiter was awesome -- 2 seconds after we sat down, he had already taken our beer orders and had the glasses in front of us.  He was really friendly, recommended the perfect amount of pizza to order and was pretty attentive throughout the meal.  I don't remember his name, but he has a goatee, I think....  We had a large pepperoni and a medium mushroom.  The mushroom pizza ROCKED.  We'll be going back for more.  DE-LISH!
author: Karen K.

description: Nice pizza place if you live in the neighborhood.  Consistently tasty pizza with fresh tomato sauce and great toppings (I absolutely love the roasted garlic!!)  They also have pretty good salads.  While it's one of the better pizzas I've had (especially compared to what they consider pizza in the Financial District), I still prefer Tomasso's to Za(though they don't deliver and their wait is much much longer).
author: seta a.

description: This is a really good place to get a slice of pizza.  It's priced reasonably and is in a great location.  The slices are nice and large.  The only thing I didn't like about this place is the staff.  The owner is a very nice guy, but the younger guys that work there all act like they're f**king all the girls that walk in or are trying to get with them.  But then again, it's russian hill, so they probably are...  Good pizza though.
author: John S.

description: Anytime I want a quick bite, I'll head to Za. Convenient, cheap, and so delicious. The thin crust meat lovers gets a thumbs up!
author: Han C.

description: My family and I were visiting San Francisco over the holidays.  We randomly picked this place for lunch.  What a great find it turned out to be!!  The service was very friendly, the portions for "slices" were very large and the pizza was so fresh and homemade! We had the veggie and kids of course had the cheese.  Yum, and my kids loved it!  My girls still remember the owner who personally served us and found my daughter's headband which she had dropped on the floor!!  This place was a memorable place for us.  Loved it!!
author: ajay and anita s.

description: We were finishing up our meal 30 minutes before closing time and the staff decided to scream... "we're closed" repeatedly, stack all the chairs up and even shuffle chairs into the table we were eating at. The young staff were definitely in a rush to leave and got their point across in a rude manner. No pizza is worth that kind of treatment.
author: Nikki D.

description: it's pretty "gourmet" tasting pizza..with a fancier twist to the typical toppings..pesto..ground sausage...to name a few....gotta say it was pretty good....for $56...2 medium 3 topping...and 2 caesar salads....the salad alone was 5 stars....it was good as my friend said...pizza was 4 stars...
author: Hen A.

description: Tasty thin cornmeal crust slices the size of home plate.
author: E C.

description: Oh man, the memories. This was one of the first places that I ate at when I visited San Francisco contemplating while I decided whether or not to move here. I thought it was damn tasty then and completely forgotten about its existence. I came back a little while ago and was super impressed. Huge slice of thin crust and the daily special I got that day were incredible. It was a slice called 'Frank's' and it had sausage, green onions and mushrooms. Damn. So good, not too greasy and we didn't have to wait long at all. The place was jam packed, so had I decided to stay and eat the wait would have been a lot longer, but I decided to get mine to go. Who knew I'd be popping in here for a slice 4 years later?
author: Michael E.

description: Za is delish!  Came here on Saturday after a long day of hiking and ordered a medium pepperoni (boring, yes, but a classic benchmark for judging a pizza!) and a couple beers.  We came around 3pm and it was almost completely empty, which really allowed for great service!  Our pizza came out surprisingly quick.  Delicious, crisp crust and cooked to perfection!  Minus one star for lack of beers on tap, but otherwise, this place is fantastic!
author: Kathleen B.

description: Great neighborhood pizza joint. My equally petite friend and I ordered the Salvadore Dali pizza and killed it with a smile! It was a little on the pricier end, but it was definitely well worth it. The crust was crispy, flakey and buttery and the ingredients were fresh and tasty. They serve beer on tap, too. Swensen's is even down the street if you're craving something sweet. What more could you ask for?
author: Natalie T.

description:
this is so good, im extremely full but i have so much left over (the slices are hugeeeee) and i dont want any to go to waste...so im gonna have just oneeeeeee more slice...oops.


everyone there is nice. i am happy.
author: Alison D.

description: They must have great gourmet slices on site, cause their standard pizza delivered isn't notable. Too much cornmeal on the crust - blech. Gave them one shot but with so many other places we really like, it's not worth trying again for delivery.
author: Mike C.

description: Za isn't really convenient unless you live close by, but the pizza is good enough for me to put on my flashers and risk a parking ticket and the ire of passing vehicles as I leave my car parked in front of the corner fire hydrant to stop in and pick up my pizza.  Definitely my favorite thin crust in the city.
author: K K.

description: Great neighborhood spot.  So close to my place for a really good slice of pizza.  Although quirky, I love the workers there.  With the service the art and the art inspired slices this place is one of my favorites in my hood.  Very big slices too which is also a plus.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
not bad for russian hill, but most definitely can't compete with the likes of pazzia or arinell. therefore, za is not a destination spot, but if i'm in russian hill, i might stop by for a slice of their decent thin crust pizza.

one thing is for sure. unlike arinell, the guys at za understand the meaning of the word "service."
author: frisco j.

description: We recently visited San Francisco and decided to stay in our hotel for dinner one night so we turned to yelp to find a good pizza delivery in the area. The rave yelp reviews and interesting menu made our decision easy and we went with this place. Unfortunately, the reviews did not equate with our experience. When we called to place our order the guy was rushed and only half paying attention. He'd interrupt to ask a question that I was already in the process of answering. I gave him explicit directions to our hotel multiple times (due to the listening problem he seemed to have) since our hotel lobby was located apart from the main hotel lobby. When the delivery driver called to let us know that he had arrived I went to meet him and found an empty lobby. I assumed that the instructions I'd given had not been shared with him and called the driver to tell him where to go. My call was received by a rude jerk who asked how he was supposed to know where to go. All in all, the pizza itself was alright. It wasn't horrible, and it wasn't great. The experience with the staff was not worth it at all. If you don't mind half-assed rude people with a decent product, go with these guys. If you want helpful staff with manners, go elsewhere.
author: Elaine M.

description: This small yet comfy neighborhood pizza joint is a good one.   They have tasty thin pizza just how I like it.   I've gotten slices to go and I've been pretty satisfied.  the sausage/mushroom pizza was delicious.   after you hit up Za's then dessert is just down the street at my favorite Swensen's.. I would definitely recommend those two spots if you're on a casual date ;)
author: T M.

description: What is it about a bad experience (see my review on North Beach) that makes a good experience that much better.  Thanks Za for getting a delicious pizza in my hands tonight.  We had a hick-up, the drinks didn't make it, but you sent some good customer service my way... and then drinks showed up later that evening.  Great pizza, good customer service... thank you!
author: Neal K.

description: We popped in here one night while visiting my sister in SF.  I was feeling a little crappy after traveling all day, but decided to order a slice anyway.  I'm glad I did because it was really tasty.  I love the cheese they use and the crispiness of the crust was right on.  My husband really enjoyed his slice too and even tried to extort some of mine.  The staff seemed really friendly but the ordering process was a little confusing.  We felt a little awkward because eventhough we were with my sister who had been there a million times, we couldn't tell if someone was going to wait on us or if we should go up to the counter to order.  If they fix that little snafu, they'll have 5-star potential in my book.
author: Becky W.

description: I called this place for the first time and when I asked if they deliver to my location the guy said, "No, absolutely not." Ouch, hostile. I live in a neighborhood that can be a bit wild but it's not horrible, and it isn't all that far away so I don't know what the problem was. I suppose I could have asked him to explain his response, but his tone was a bit shocking so I just I hung up.
author: Jill M.

description: Pizza is very average and greasy. Service is horrible and the guy who runs the place is a total jerk. Don't waste your time and money here. There are plenty of great places in San Francisco for good pizza. Try Coppola's in North Beach instead. They have the most authentic Naples-style pizza in the city.
author: Alberto B.

description: Best pizza in the city-hands down.  I get the "Da Vinci Palette," it's delicious.
author: Crystal W.

description: This is the best thin crust pizza I've found in this city. I'm a huge fan of the cornmeal crust. Fortunately, this place is on my commute home!
author: Neil K.

description: With so much care taken in putting together a top-notch pizza pie, this place won my heart instantly!  The crust is golden and crispy and not the type of stuff you'd leave on the plate.  The ingredients are fresh and cooked to perfection with the perfect amount of cheese and sauce to accompany them.  With the ambiance of a neighborhood pizza joint, friendly owners and great music, this Hyde Street staple is not to miss.  Plus, the pizza slices are enormous!
author: ellyk E.

description: Great flavor on the pizza.  We ordered a basic tomato, cheese, garlic, and basil pizza.  A bit expensive at $20 for a Medium but this is no Domino's pizza.  We wanted to try a simple pizza first.  It was really really flavorful with the garlic basil and tomatoes.  Unfortunately the crust wasn't too crispy considering it was a thin crust pizza, maybe it was slightly undercooked?  I will go back again and try a different pizza.  the specialty pizzas are all $20 (even the ones with meat).  Space is limited inside so we got our pizza to go.
author: Emiko M.

description: I can't eat  pizza anywhere else anymore. try my specialty - pesto base with roasted garlic and sweet Italian sausage. three slices = delectable food coma. guaranteed.
author: rahmin s.

description: I think this is a great little place for pizza. I have never eaten in, only ordered out and I think the pizza is great! The crust is crispy, the cheese melts in your mouth, and the toppings taste amazing... I don't live in the neighborhood anymore but any chance I get I stop in for some tasty pizza...
author: Miguel V.

description:
1/15/11 @ 6pm
Have you ever wanted to try a new place just to make sure you weren't missing out on something amazing? Well this is one of those places you try because of the yelp hype and you instantly regret it. There are half a dozen other places that delivery with better flavor, value and customer service. (I'm biased to Victors) 
Pizza Taste: Somewhere between thin crusted pizza and cardboard. The dough was tough and hard. Not to be confused with chewy and delicious. The toppings average at best. The ground sausage pieces would have been nice except they fall everywhere. 
Delivery: "I only deliver to the entryway of your building." No really, he actually said that. The delivery guy did not want to use the front door intercom because he doesn't deliver pizza to your  apartment. He later explained he parked in a bus stop. Did I tell you to park there? Wasn't there a driveway you could have parked in for a second?
Customer Service: When I pay to have you deliver it, I expect you to come to my apartment not halfway there. Second, if you are delivering an order check you have all the items (such as a second pizza and no salad) before berating your customers and saying next time i have to walk down. P.S. Dont worry, I wont have to walk downstairs because I'm never ordering from you again.
author: ray c.

description: Our office ordered pizza here for the first time for our Weekly Pizza Friday, which is a bit better than the Bagel Friday at my former agency.  And I am happy to say that this is the best pizza that I've had so far in San Francisco.  Size matters, and the pieces are HUGE.  I mean I brought piece home for take out and it was so wide that it hardly fit in my microwave oven.  They pile the toppings on so I was stuffed after eating just 1 slice!
author: Amy Z.

description:
When I first moved to San Francisco, I lived a half a block away from this spot.  Back in 05, they didn't have the 3 stoner counter boys that take your order while chugging red wine (although, sometimes they prefer the Hef on tap, or they might even buy their own Miller Light bottles from the mini-mart down the street).  You know what?  The place hasn't changed a bit, and the corn-meal crusted, relatively thin crust pizza hasn't gone down hill....at all.  
In fact, their slices with LOADS of fresh veggies and minimal amounts of sauce really do the job.  It's like they're working overtime.  Artichokes, tomatoes, peppers, basil, mushrooms, spinach, you name it.  It's all fresh and they never cheap out on the toppings.  
Yes, the place is small, but that's what a pizZA place in the hood should be like.  Those who complain about the delivery service....I don't have much to say to you.  They don't hire dozens of formerly unemployed idiots to bring you your grub.  They only have a couple people to get in their car and drive it to you.  So if you want it hot and crispy, eat there.
Oh, and I should mention that their green salad is AWESOME and the portion is very generous.  Get the basil vinagrette.  
Finally, I'm from the East coast ( we get the NY-influenced recipes, so we kind of have better pizza) and generally feel like a lot of pizza here in SF is sub-par.  Not here...this place is the best.
author: Spice O.

description: Za is my favorite pizza in the city, but after the treatment we got there last night, I'm never going back. Too many good choices to deal with mean staff. We called for a carry out and asked if we could eat it when we got there. The nice guy on the phone said that if there were tables available, we could. Tables were open when we got there. I went to ask the guy working the floor if there was a wait for the open tables and he immediately gave me attitude. I mean, really rude and dismissive. When we sat down, I tried to tell him we'd placed a carry-out order and wanted to eat it there. Three new people walked in and the guy yelled something to the effect "So what?! You're gonna make these people wait cuz you called ahead? That's not how it works." He continued to tell us, in front the entire restaurant how rude we were, even as people next to us were leaving and offering up their table. I don't have an issue with their policy. If they won't let you sit to eat a slice of your carry-out, that's cool. But to be so mean and ugly, even as we were buying our pizza and leaving, is beyond me. Sadly, I'll be telling everyone I know, especially our friends who are regulars like us. Fastest way to lose business: be rude to your customers. Doesn't matter how good your product is. We live in a city of great choices. Za, fire the asshole and I'll come back.
author: Amy H.

description: I really liked the 2 lots o' toppings pizzas, but not the pepperoni, and my conclusion is that I dont' really like their sauce, its too sweet for my tastes.  So pizza with lots of toppings 5 stars pizza with no toppings 3 stars.  It can get pretty loud in here.  They seemed genuinely interested in accomadating people.  If you are a girl be prepared to be flirted with.
author: b s.

description: Za Pizza is great! Pizzas there are fantastically delicious!  The employees are always really nice and welcoming, which is really nice.  If you've had the pizza from Escape from New York, then this pizza is very similar. They serve beer and a couple wines, and they do have pizza by the slice.  Definitely a neighborhood spot in Russian Hill!
author: Courtney M.

description:
Za is exactly what you want from a pizza place.  Nothing too pretentious and the pizza is one of the best in the city.  Also the salads are generously sized and also very good.

Busy, chilled out atmosphere, grab a beer and a table and just kick it.
author: C. H.

description: Jose and the boys still hold it down, delivering one of the best slices in the whole town. Saddle up at the bar, get a pint, and grind on a super sized salad and a Da Vinci's Palate, or Potesto, or Mama's Slice. Remember when they had a little hole in the wall spot on Polk. Karl Watson would give out free pizzas to all my friends and I, sitting on our skateboards double fisting cheese slices. Secured Za's legacy in my mind.
author: Sam S.

description: Not much new here to say -- tasty and affordable pizzas and salads and good beers on tap.
author: Megan S.

description:
Za's doesn't make the best pizza. It is, however, one of the most comfortable spots in the city to belly up to the bar, order an Anchor Steam (or 2) on tap, eat some very yummy pizza, watch whatever sports team is playing today on the tube, and even listen to vintage Bowie or Zeppelin if you're lucky. The guys working there (haven't really noticed any female staffers) are very cool and helpful. 
Za's is not even CLOSE to my neighborhood, but I  love them so much, I shlep up over the hill every couple of weeks just to feel cozy and wonderful.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
the corn meal makes it different. the flavors are good. it's interesting. it's no traditional pizza. it's tasty tho. i grew up in manhattan so i'm a pizza "snob" so take that as you will. 

Arnell? Check. Little Star? Check. Giorgio's? Double check check (and maybe a third check). Za? Sure, why not.
author: who k.

description: Ok I love Za Pizza. When I lived in the Marina this was an easy place to get to - sometimes for walk-ins late afternoon on weekends. Now that I live on the other side of the city, it takes about 20 minutes to get to Za, and I have to eat this pizza piping hot! It is so delicious - I always get the pepperoni and a salad. So delicious! I daresay one of the best in the city!
author: Mariangela S.

description: I'm not typically a lass who gets excited about pizza. I mean, it's just a bunch of dough with sauce on top, right? Not so at Za's, where I recently feasted on a crisp thin-crusted slice laden with all my favorite goodies - artichoke hearts, garlic, sun-dried tomatoes, mushrooms and spinach (back when spinach was our friend). The portion was ample and the ratio of topping-to-crust was pleasingly weighted toward the former. Nigh pizza perfection for under five bucks.
author: Leela S.

description: After Pizza My Heart closed, my heart broke.  Za is a good substitute.  I've never eaten in the restaurant - I always order take-out.  HOWEVER, I detest calling that place.  In fact, I beg my husband to call!  The noise level on the phone is atrocious, and because I have to scream my order, I spend the next 45 minutes praying they actually got my order right.  I do like the pizza, and the crust is quite tasty (a make or break for me).
author: Carrie R.

description: I am as picky with pizza as my pizza monster and so this place really nails it for us. We order take out from here all the time since it is near our hoods. It definitely hits the spot. Dali is the way to go on one side and on the other side we normally get something on the simpler side such as mushrooms and some type of sausage. Slices are very generous. I recommend dipping in ranch and of course drinking with some refreshing beer to complete the meal. I am getting hungry just writing this...
author: Bernadette L.

description:
I salivate as I think about this place.  I celebrated my last birthday with this pizza.  I do love local places like Zacharys and Little Star, but when it comes to thin crust goodness, Za Pizza is definitely my go-to place.  It does seem a little bit more expensive to the chain places, but their pies are sized accordingly.  A "medium" is about the size of a "large" anywhere else.

They have a great selection of toppings, but my default order is pepperoni and spinach.  If you're looking for single slices, stop by their place over on Hyde Street (good luck finding parking if you don't live in Russian Hill) and walk in and grab a piece for $3-something dollars.  It feels very NYC/Greenwich Village to me in that sense.

There are a few tables here which are never empty.  I wouldn't say this place has great ambiance, nor would I particularly rave about their wine.  Both are cheap.  But the owner is a very nice guy who is just trying to "make it in the world" with his wife.  They have a home in Petaluma but he spends a lot of nights in a modest apartment a few blocks from the place.  He's great to talk to about the Bay Area and takes great care of the guys who work for him.  You can tell that his pizza shop is a total labor of love.

So between the awesome pizza and good-natured feel of this place, I can assert with confidence that this is my very favorite thin crust pizza in the Bay Area.  Well done, Za... you're the best!
author: Lindsay M.

description: Za Pizza is located in a great neighborhood...like leasa says..."it's got that neighborhood feeling." They have great artwork on the walls...4 great beers on tap...AND they serve wine...oh yeah...they had this delish red wine from Portugal...mmm...their caesar salad yummy...i had a pesto pizza with garlic and artichoke...yummy...The entire staff was super friendly. Especially Butters!
author: Marla V.

description: All it took was one cheese slice to show why this is the Kingpin of pizza in this city. Well, I have yet to be maimed by the prices of Little Star and Amecis, but I will be shocked if they even come close the matching the perfection on dough, sauce, and cheese like Za's. I watched the staff make the pies and there is a lot of love put into the food here. Enormous, fresh salads and beer on tap. I will go as far as to say that this is the best pizza I've consumed since I visited Italy a couple of years back. The #19 takes you right to Green Street too folks. Rock it.
author: Kenny G.

description: Tasted absolutely delicious and was cheap.  Cozy little street, cool vibe.  Nicely done.  Sidewalk seating and hipster waiters. It's frickin awesome.  A bit slow and staff have attitudes but it's totally worth it.
author: Anon A.

description: Over the past four years I've come to realize that the "homeboyz" that work here definitely pick and choose who they want to serve. Za is now known as "Racist Pizza" in my book. Please do not support this place.
author: Ed C.

description: great pizza and friendly service.  slices are sold from what they have made, usually two special types of slices (meat lovers, veggie etc.), and of course cheese and pepperoni or you can create your own whole pizza.  they have a few selections of salad as well which are good.  i have eaten here a few times and have also been satisfied.
author: Christina C.

description: I have eaten at Delfina...ZA is still my favorite pizza I have eaten in SF.  I'm so lucky to be in "delivery" range of this pizzeria.  My fav. is half scaliano and half Moma.  Gotta check this place out!
author: Britt B.

description: Kick ass pizza.  Kick ass salads.  Kick ass crew.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: 27 dollars for a large pizza, we think thats fair.  That's what we should charge even though we are rude on the phone for delivery orders, don't listen to Jukes when he says he wants his pizza "well done, extra crispy, honestly almost burn it " three times, and we use too much corn meal on the crust.  But we're on top of this hill so let's mark it up!
author: Julian M.

description: wowza!  amazing thin crust pizza!  hit all of the right spots and the ingredients were so fresh.  we went there based on the yelp reviews and were certainly not disappointed at all.  of course we didn't order a pizza combo they suggested and went with what we wanted on our pizza and it was still great.  great pizza and really fast service!
author: Jubi N.

description: East coast style. Dig the thin, cornmeal crust. Delish. The music-blaring, ultra-cozy ambiance isn't  my style-- good thing the pizza is!
author: Kezia P.

description:
Hubby and I found this place by accident, or maybe he had it all planned out, I never know with him. 

Anyway, we liked this place a lot. Not a super thin, cracker crust kinda place but thin crust and good. We got Da Vinci's Palette (sausage, peppers and onions and added on anchovies) and Monet's Garden salad with honey mustard dressing. The salads are huge by the way and also pretty damn good. Great customer service, nice atmosphere and I swear it's always the little things that get me to like a place. Twice when we were eating I noticed their pizza chef sweeping out the ovens for burnt flour before cooking a new batch of pizza. I don't know about much of you, but I kinda liked that they knew that burnt flour on the bottom of your pizza crust must not be too tasty. I also liked the neighborhood feel of the place, they clearly had a lot of regulars/friends stopping by and that's always cool. This place can be a little too loud but the great pizza far outweighs a little hearing damage. Plus, Swensen's is just up the street, pizza and then ice cream for a chaser, that's a good meal.
author: cora j.

description: I like this place a lot.  We usually get the sausage and mushroom.  Thin crust and nice large slices.  We have had a few times for our weekly Pizza Friday celebration at work and it's always a huge hit.  Oh! And they usually have cute boys working at the counter which is a perk of dining at the restaurant...Check it out!
author: PictureGirl F.

description: This place rocks! They have creative, amazing pizza, and good beers. The vibe is very casual yet a bit funky, so you feel cool eating pizza there with friends (like it's more of an outing than just grabbing a slice at any old pizza place.) My friends and I always get the Pesto Picasso and the Mona Lisa. SOOOO good! You won't be disappointed.
author: Jamie C.

description: The Vincent Van Dough is the best specialty pizza -- simple but so good. The potesto pizza is also really good but I tried some of their other specialty pizzas and always go back to the Vincent Van Dough. The pizzas are pretty expensive but it's the best place to get delivered when you're at a sports bar watching the game with some friends. I've never eaten at the actual place because I'm far too lazy to walk to any area in SF that has the word "hill" in it (which limits my options severely) but their delivery service has always been good to my lazy ass.
author: Esther K.

description: Good, but based on reviews I was expecting some amazing New York style pizza.  It was okay, but the first tip off was the cornmeal dusting on the bottom - what is this, Domino's?  Real new york places do not use cornmeal.  And the crust was light and thin, but didn't have the texture that makes a pizza amazing or memorable.  Overall, a decent place for tasty pizza, but not necessarily NY style pizza.
author: Ben K.

description: Za's PIzza is right around the corner from the apartment my wife and I are renting for a few days here in San Francisco. We called to order a Salvador Dali (roasted chicken, sun-dried tomatoes, pesto and sauce) and it was ready for pick-up twenty minutes later. The pizza was excellent: thin crust, corn meal on the bottom, tangy sun-dried tomatoes that offset the savory roasted chicken. It was the perfect way to end a long day driving up from L.A.
author: Tim G.

description:
Vincent Van Dough.  Nuff said.  It is the only tomato-basil pizza I have ever truly loved.  It is topped with fresh chopped tomatoes, loads of fresh garlic, and fresh basil.  You know, almost every pizzeria has some version of a margherita pizza, but this is the most flavorful I have ever had.  I think it's because I'm a garlic fan, and the guys definitely don't short-change you on it.

I also always order a Caesar salad because they make a really tasty version of it a Za.  Like my favorite pizza here, the dressing is heavy on the garlic!  A small is large enough to share for two or three people.

On my first visit, I ordered a slice of meat pizza.  It was only average.  The reheating process made the crust too hard to eat.  Now, I only come here when I have someone else to dine with so we can order a whole, freshly made Vincent Van Dough.

Za is located on a charming section of Hyde Street.  The interior is small but nicely decorated.  Sometimes the music is too loud.  And sometimes it is impossible to get a table.  But it is the Vincent Van Dough that keeps me very loyal.  Can I say Vincent Van Dough a few more times? Vincent Van Dough Vincent Van Dough Vincent Van Dough Vincent Van Dough Vincent Van Dough....................Just order it!
author: t l.

description:
walked in on a weekday afternoon

friendly "real" people working... not some tool saying "WELCOME to (insert corporate scum name here) MAY I TAKE YOUR ORDER?

slices were a bit pricey at first glance, but size, taste, and freshness made me feel like i was robbing the place. self-serve water was nice too. i hate bothering servers for something im not paying (or tipping) for...

I loved the art on the walls, and it was not too crowded. Parking sucks in this neighborhood, but have faith... cause its worth it!
author: c e.

description: Props to ZA for trying to re-create the East Coast pizza vibe.  Order a large between 2 and you'll be eating it for 3 sqares for the next 72 hours.  Staff was friendly and although small, we had no probs scoring a table for 2 at 8:30pm on a Friday night.
author: George K.

description:
Yes - 5 stars.  Gawd, I love this place.  

Star 1:  The pizza:  I only ever order the Potesto, but it's AWESOME
Star 2:  The service:  They're so nice to everyone, especially if you're a regular.  Per some previous reviews, I think girls are treated better, and since I'm a girl, it rocks!
Star 3:  The beer:  Bottomless glasses  . . . .
Star 4:  The ambiance:  Art on the walls + sports on TV + kickass music + eye candy for the ladies (and maybe some boys) = Happy
Star 5:  The location:  It's steps away from Swensen's Ice Cream (if you're not already full) and Polk St bars (if your beer glass does, in fact, have a bottom)
author: January P.

description: Actually I'm a little pissed off at Za... but thats only becuase I know that I'm gonna gain about 40 lbs in the next few months while living off of nothing other than their potesto or pestato (or whatever the fuck you want to call it) and sierra on tap.  Thanks alot guys, I'll send you the bill for my new size 46 pants with the elastic waistband.
author: Jason L.

description: Every time I've been the food has always been really tasty. I love their salads and they serve beer & wine! The food is affordable which is also really nice.
author: Eva C.

description: Ok, so first off it's been over a year since I've had Za so I will owe them an update after I have another visit. My guy loves Za, but I've always preferred NB Pizza over them. They do have creative toppings, but I was never really excited about any of them after we ordered. The crust is a little thin for my taste, i prefer a thicker crust. The delivery takes a long time every time we've ordered too so that's always a bummer. We have ordered from them sevral times though and if it really wasn't good I wouldn't be going back, so I guess I'm just indifferent, they aren't my favorite but definitely aren't the worst either. I'll give them another shot in 09 and then update it incase I'm forgetting anything exciting that would warrant an extra star.
author: Audrey V.

description: Huge slices, very yummy toppings.  I had a slice for which I cannot remember the name, but it had hot Italian sausage, tomatoes, garlic, and maybe one other thing.  It was really really good.  Salads are equally large.  The small was enough to share.  I love thin, crsipy-ish crust pizza so this place is now near the tops of my list for 'za.  But word of warning:  went there on a Friday night and it was crowded, which was fine, but also LOUD.  Deafeningly loud.
author: darla s.

description: Minus one star for the slightly too sweet sauce, and the fact we had tor remind the waiter twice what we ordered. But still, it was insanely good and cheap. The slice of pizza was HUGE. So was the salad I wolfed down waiting for the damn slice.
author: H H.

description: I enjoyed the thin pizza and their salad was great too.   I had it delivered so I have no idea what the service is like.
author: Seong P.

description: i actually love this pizza.  Yeah, the crust can be a little too thin for the amount of ingredients piled on, but it is delicious!  Especially their combos with sausage.  Just be prepared for woefully inconsistent service, and cold shoulders if you're over 30.  I also suspect good service requires a secret nod or handshake.  One of these days I'll figure it out...then beware, evil Za masters!
author: AMY B.

description: Neighborhood joint with good thin crust pizza.  It's always buzzing at dinner time.  Huge slices and salads.  It's the best pizza place that you have never been to.  The staff is made up of aging skater boys.
author: T-Bone L.

description: The pizza here is all right.  Great toppings but the crust was ridiculously soggy.  The service was also kind of bizarre.  One guy in particular had a chip on his shoulder and acted like it was a huge pain in the ass to do anything for us.  I don't think I'll ever go back - a good crust is key & they just really missed the mark.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Man, I love this place. I'm a pizza purist, and I just loves me a good slice of cheese. And these guys bring it. Perfectly cooked crust, tasty sauce and definitely not too greasy or cheesy. Its a fun spot too and you can get some great beer on tap. It's nowhere near my house, in fact its on the polar opposite of the city, but anytime I'm in the area, I'll be stopping by.
author: Brandon B.

description: The place is pretty small.  Theres a few tables that are too big for the place.  And it's always packed.  Order a pizza or just order by the slice.  I usually recommend the slice of the day with a beer.  Their salads are huge and delicious too.  And the guys who work there are super chill.  This place is awesome.
author: Lauren M.

description: Every Friday night, my husband either orders or goes to get a pizza for us while I am out in the evening. Their pizza is always perfectly cooked, service is exceptionally good. My daughter had her first pizza from Za when she was 2 year old, she is 9 now and it is still her favorite pizza.
author: M B.

description: There is a big debate between my friends and I whether Za Pizza or Little Star are the best. I am not a huge deep dish fan and I do prefer orderign a custom made pie so Za gets 2 thumbs up from me. My friends that live south of Market are not too happy they do not deliver there, but that doesn't apply to me so I'm happy. They key to great pizza is the sauce and crust. Try the Pepperoni, Mushroom, and extra cheese pizza. So good.
author: Randy N.

description: Great Pizza.... definitely on par with the All-Stars and Delfina's of the culinary world!
author: Jon C.

description: Great place to go for a quick bite.  THis is a fun neighborhood place that does not require much of a plan.  It is easy and low key.  The pesto pizza is my fav!
author: Jaime C.

description: Great pizza and ceaser salad. The only gripe I have about this place is that they play their music WAY too loud! It's good music, it just needs to be put down a few notches. When we asked if they could turn it down they gave us this as their answer "There is only two setting for the volume". WTF?? Whatever, just don't come here if you want to talk to the people you are noshing on your pizza with.
author: Ericka A.

description: I hate to be a naysayer but I just didn't like it. I like thin crust pizza but I found this one not very flavorful and the sun dried tomato very chewy and hard to eat. Perhaps it's because I got one of their specials and not a regular slice but I don't think I'll be going back anytime soon.
author: Cathy T.

description: I wouldn't call this gourmet food but it is delicious. The neopolitan stuff with garlic is pretty addictive. The crust is a little thick and big for my taste, but it is nonetheless tender and tasty. The one things I don't like about the place is for "gourmet" joint it is way ghetto (haha), it's slightly overpriced, and the cheese they use lacks quality. It's rubbery. And I am not sure why anyone said there is street parking available there because you cannot park anywhere in San Francisco.
author: Y K.

description: My favorite pizza place in SF, above Delfina. The slices are always fresh and delicious, the staff is super nice, maybe because we go there every week. It feels like vacation when you can savor your slice sitting outside. Their garden salad is a great addition to the pizza.
author: Helene L.

description:
Their pizza is no better and no worse than most other pizzas. I know, this sounds ambiguous but how else can you say "hum drum" pizza?

Seating is very limited and there is a nice view of the Hyde Street cable car going by.
author: John C.

description: mmmmm... my Favorite!  Great pizza, beer & neighborhood friends!  Makes for the best roommate outing (followed by an obligatory nightcap at the Buck, of course)!
author: Mara H.

description: There is no great pizza in San Francisco!  Za's is great as far as "gourmet" pizza goes.  If you want ooey gooey cheese pizza, you won't find it there.  When you have to dust off the crust, you know it's an issue.
author: Jean C.

description: This rating would be 5 stars if Za could get their effing service in order.  I crave their pizza.  I adore it like none other.  It's comparable to New Haven pizza.  But I cannot stand their punk-ass, too-cool-for-school staff.  Nor can I handle the 2-hour wait for delivery (I swear that on Monday night we ordered at 7:32 and the pizza arrived at 9:35).  One time, we were so ignored (and horribly treated when they did deign to pay us attention) that I witnessed my mild-mannered boyfriend, who I have seen lose it only 3 times in almost 3 years, undergo a complete meltdown.  We swore Za off for about 3 months, and then could not resist its siren song.  Curse you, Za!
author: Pamela D.

description: I don't eat Pizza unless I am with my friend Brooke.....seems like we have happened on this place a few times.  The veggie pizza is super yummy....
author: Tracy M.

description: can't say i'm into the potesto pizza, but i think the idea that they even have such a variation should tell everyone why they have to go there! the flavors of the day are always awesome and if you're a picky eater, they have the standards, pepperoni & cheese, by the slice, too. I walk by here everyday from the bus. somehow, if i see spicy or sweet italian sausage on the board, i get sucked into the place. not that i'm really complaining though.. i have to say the ultimate night cap (ex-mondays) is Swenson's for a little ice cream!
author: Heidi L.

description: I'm on the hunt for the best "slice" in this city and so far Za in the running (I'd say top 3).  Good slice and they don't add too much sauce which is a classic mistake.  Be prepared to shout your order as this place can get extremely loud at times.   The boys behind the counter could use take a "service" lesson from time to time.
author: Tom C.

description: Had a slice of the pepperoni and a slice of the special (M.O.M.A. artichokes, onions, spinach, etc). Both were great with a crispy and thin crust, but the M.O.M.A. was definitely better. They also have a great selection of beers on tap and a couple of outdoor tables...
author: Nicolas H.

description: This place is super cute with local art hanging on the walls and faux painted walls.  Gives an urban yet cozy feel, but it can get crowded very quickly so go early if you can.  And....the pizza is finger lickin' good!  I especially like the fresh, thin crust and the "Dali" which combines fresh tomatoe sauce and cheese with pesto drizzled all over it here and there. Mmmmmmm.  They deliver too!
author: Stacy M.

description: We live a few blocks from this place, so it is definately one of the best pizza placees within walking distance.  The staff is nice, and the bar is clean and has some nice beer.  However, this pizza is not nearly as good as an average NY pizza.  Or Boston.  Don't know what it is.  Everything seems just right, but there isn't enough salt in the dough, or perhaps the sauce?  I don't know.  I've got some friends from Boston coming next week, so we'll see what they say.  Maybe I'm just too picky.  In any case, this beats most places in California!
author: Alexander T.

description: Holy cow! Is this potato on my pizza?! Gourmet pizza at it's finest. The boss ordered several pizzas on the recommendation of one of my coworkers who happens to live around the block from Za. I hardly every deviate from my usual pepperoni pizza, but I'll sell my body for another bite of that pizza with the potatoes on it! (Yeah, not really.)
author: Michael R.

description: The staff is extremely freindly in this little Russian Hill hole in the wall, only partly because most of them are totally baked, and the atmosphere is so relaxed I feel almost like I am sitting in my own living room.    The pizza is amazing.  I am usually not a big fan of sausage, but for some reason Za's sausage is really good.  Not cheap, but well worth it.
author: Brad K.

description: I think this is the best thin crust pizza in SF. Their salads are huge. Their beer selection is solid. I just am not all that crazy about pizza in SF to begin with. The sauce is a little mild on taste. I am a fan of most of their meats and cheese as far as quality of toppings. I have come here alot and always taken good care of my waiters, so I don't know why I get weak service that is where the one star comes off for me. All in all I vote yes.
author: Sean Q.

description: We were in San Francisco's Russian Hill, and stopped by for a pizza at Za. It was fantastic! I had the Cesar salad, which was huge and had a great flavor. We ordered a pepperoni pizza, and you could taste the love that went into the pizza. The atmosphere is fun, and we sat and had a beer and watched the basketball game. When we are back in San Francisco we will definitely be back to Za!
author: Leslie W.

description: Gonna say I like there Pizza a lot.  I find myself going here more and more these day when I get the Za urge.   North Beach used to be my standard, but I don't think it really compares crust wise.  It's a little crispy underneath with a taste of crunchy corn meal.   I've read some of the other reviews that bag on the service, which I would have to agree with for the most part.  It is, however a pizza place.  My expectations are not very high when sitting down for a large pizza and some beers but that seems to be a bitchy challenge to the staff.  It's whatever though.  Good pizza in a stellar location.  Not exactly something I would drive to, considering the parking in the neighborhood is next to impossible (for the evening at least) but I would pay a visit for lunch or an early bite to eat.  Try the MoMa or the Dali.
author: Brad C.

description: Amendment: I am that lazy.  I got DELIVERY recently (see previous interview, I live 4 blocks away) and it was awesome.  I got no judgment or grief for asking them to deliver so close.  The guy was actually really nice about it.  I LOVE ZA!
author: Angela S.

description:
A lot of sensibilities get lost in translation from the East Coast to the West.  The most glaring is what people consider to be good pizza.  Za's is a perfect example of this.  The pizza is good but not great, its actually one of the best in San Francisco but thats not saying much.  To compare it to New York or any other northeast pizza town is out of line.  Furthermore, the price is absurdly expensive.  $20 dollars for a medium pepperoni pizza is nuts.  Its pizza.  Which reminds me, potatoes and pesto is not pizza call it whatever you want but its not pizza.

Overall, for San Francisco, the pizza is probably the best your going to get but for the price your better off going to get a burrito or something that San Francisco knows how to make.
author: Ryan B.

description: I'm way into the specials here, from the pesto to meat concoctions. The pepperoni and cheese slices also do the job well. In general, I usually buy (and finish) two slices whenever I get pizza, but the slices I've had here are big and hearty enough so I only need one. I just moved around the corner, so I'm content that I can walk over for pizza -- or a pint or two of beer -- during the day.
author: Cheri R.

description: The pizza here is fantastic but the ex-frat boys behind the counter provide some of the worst customer service I've experienced in the city. I've waited for 5-10 minutes while four or five of them stand around like morons.
author: Brenda S.

description: I went here for lunch today. Small little restaurant, kind of dark, but we sat outside so it was cool. It is really cheap (around $5 a slice for the gourmet pizza), but they give you a huge slice, even a little bigger than a Costco slice. I tried the Bluto pizza, which had spinach, sweet sausage, and feta cheese. It was pretty good. The Caesar salad was also immense (small size was enough for 3 people!) and tasty. I still prefer Pizzetta 211.
author: O K.

description: I have heard about Za's for months now.  I have heard that it is the best pizza in the city, that I have to go here, and that I won't be disappointed.  I was only a little disappointed because I didn't feel like my pizza was cheesy enough (I love cheese).  However, it still tasted pretty damn good.  I had the salad, which was huge (enough for two meals alone).  I then also had a slice of pizza, which clearly was really three slices of pizza.  Say what you want - this place is certainly generous with portions.
author: Joanna S.

description: A good pie for the price.  Small place in a great neighborhood but parking is tough.
author: Scott A.

description:
Screw this place!!! I always go with the old stand-by's and wanted to try something new. I called at 7:15 yesterday (Sunday). The person who answered the phone and took my order said it would be 30 minutes. I ran a few errands and then pulled up to get my pizza.

After I paid, she starts making small talk. She was just trying to butter me up because she eventually spilled the beans that something happened and they didn't make my pizza yet. Of course, it was after I paid. She says that are just putting it in the oven and it would take 8 minutes. OK, why does it take 30 minutes before and only 8 now? 

They didn't even offer to make it right. One guy offered a beer, but I'm sure if i said 'yes' they would've charged me. They acted like they didn't give a shit that they had kept me waiting 30 minutes or that they screwed up the order. Also, there were two people drinking whiskey behind the counter. They were probably half in the bag. In addition, one other person was behind the counter sitting off to the side, picking his nose. I don't believe he was actually working, but he's back there diggin for gold. 

I finally got home and the pizza wasn't even that good. I'd rather have North Beach Pizza any day over this. Even if you have great pizza (which it wasn't) you still shouldn't be so indifferent to people, especially when the restaurant makes the mistakes. 

I really feel like it's a bunch of drunken frat buddies that thought it'd be a great idea to open a pizza place. They seem to be more concerned about goofing off and having a good time rather than creating a quality pizza/atmosphere. Their customer service blows!!!!

DON'T GO HERE
author: Erik B.

description: Reading some of these other reviews makes me wonder if I ate at the same place.  I ordered delivery, had to call back three times, the first time I called back was after being hung up on, and then on hold for FIFTEEN minutes. I put it on speaker after five minutes on hold, and started doing something else, completely forgot that I was on the phone with them. They finally came back on the line, I still ordered the pie and when it arrived twenty minutes after they said it would, it was cold and well below average.  I ate two slices, and gave the rest away.
author: Scott R.

description:
Pizza is pretty good here if you like thin crust and lots of good toppings.  The place is pretty cute, the artwork is kinda weird, and the guys working behind the place seem to be really..ehm..reeeally into girls.  One was just staring...staring..staring at our table, I was doing that look away awkwardly kind of thing.  And then one of my friends asked for ranch sauce and they unfortunately didn't have it....ok, no big deal..but the guy ran outside and got us a bottle from the corner store.  Now that's very considerate of him, but.....well ok..just kinda weird.  So we just thought he was very nice..and then, continuing in his never-ending stare, he offered our table a free round of beers..awesome!!--Until we got the bill which our lady waitress served us WITH the beer on the tab...but I..but I thought it was free...

Service is kind of confusing, but other than that the pizza is pretty good and the salads looked enormous and really tasty.  Next time I'll order a salad too..and I'll go when I'm feeling ugly and unwanted so my spirits can be lifted by staring pizza man.
author: Trisha H.

description:
Not gonna try to be a snob here, but I wanted to share an experience that has stuck with me in one my trips down there (which happens to be the last time I've dropped by).

They've got some pretty unique pizzas here but it's nothing out of the ordinary. Big slices though so that's a plus.

But watch out for the guy with the shoulder length blond hair with the beanie working there. He's a total asshole (maybe not to the ladies). Along with that, the service can get really shitty even when it's not busy.  I stood there for nearly 10 minutes waiting to get an order in while this other douchebag worker, who CLEARLY saw me at the register was trying to flirt it up with some woman sitting at the bar who probably had no interest in him. Along with that, one of the female workers kept walking past me, not even bothering to ask if I needed help with anything.

Other than those three bums though, service is OK. Owner is a real nice guy.

So in short: Pizza A-OK. Service can be full of garbage at times though.
author: J C.

description: Big slices...HUGE. Great daily specials and a laid back scene. Right down the hill from Swensen's as well. Definitely some of the better pizza in S.F...if only the hills you need to walk up to get to this place were a little smaller...
author: Mike P.

description: The pies are tasty and the salads delish.  Za earned a place in my heart forever when I noticed that the staff were throwing back shots in the kitchen.
author: Marcus C.

description: Some of the best pizza in town! yes, you'll get a little attitude from their stuff but that's part of what makes them good! love their choice of music and the crowd.
author: Heiko L.

description:
i've searched high and low all over the greater nob hill area, and after many disappointments, a few inedibilities, and a couple of violent illnesses, i've  finally found the holy grail of delivery pizzas. 

the last star will have to be earned by improvements in speed of service, in both order-taking and delivery.
author: Joanne L.

description: I lived in NYC for 7 yrs before moving to SF and am a snob when it comes to pizza. Za is hands down the best pizza in SF. Their menu is creative and I've never had a bad slice there...
author: Chirpy M.
